Running title reads: The witches of Lancashire.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: A well received Comedy, lately Acted at the Globe on the Banke-side, by the Kings Majesties Actors.
WRITTEN, By THOM. HEYWOOD, AND RICHARD BROOME.
LONDON, Printed by Thomas Harper for Benjamin Fisher, and are to be sold at his Shop at the Signe of the Talbot, without Aldersgate. 1634.

lg.l: COrrantoes sailing, and no foot post late
Possessing us with Newe; of forraine State,
No accidents abroad worthy Relation
Arriving here, we are forc'd from our owne Nation
To ground the Scene that's now in agitation.
The Project unto many here well knowne;
Those Witches the fat Iaylor brought to Towne,
An Argument so thin, persons so low
Can neither yeeld much matter, nor great show.
Expect no more than can from such be rais'd,
So may the Scene passe pardoned, though not prais'd.

div.head: ACTVS, I. SCENA, I.
div.stage: Enter Master Arthur, Mr. Shakstone, Mr. Bantam: (as from hunting.)

lg.l: Was ever sport of expectation,
Thus crost in th' height.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Tush these are accidents, all game is (subject to.

lg.l: So you may call them
Chances, or crosses, or what else you please,
But for my part, Ile hold them prodigies,
As things transcending Nature.
O you speake this,
Because a Hare hath crost you.
A Hare? a Witch, or rather a Divell I think.
For tell me Gentlemen, was't possible
In such a faire course, and no covert neere,
We in pursuit, and she in constant view,
Our eyes not wandring but all bent that way,
The Dogs in chase, she ready to be ceas'd,
And at the instant, when I durst have layd
My life to gage, my Dog had pincht her, then
To vanish into nothing!

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Somewhat strange, but not as you inforce it,

lg.l: Make it plaine
That I am in an error, sure I am
That I about me have no borrow'd eyes.
They are mine owne, and Matches.
She might find some Muse as then not visible to us,
And escape that way.
Perhaps some Foxe had earth'd there,
And though it be not common, for I seldome
Have knowne or heard the like, there squat her selfe,
And so her scape appeare but Naturall,
Which you proclaime a Wonder.
Well well Gentlemen, be you of your own faith, but (what I see
And is to me apparent, being in sence,
My wits about me, no way tost nor troubled,
to that will I give credit.
Come, come, all men
Were never of one minde, nor I of yours.
To leave this argument, are you resolv'd
Where we shall dine to day?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes where we purpos'd.

sp.speaker: Banth.
sp.p: That was with Master Generous.

lg.l: True, the same.
And where a loving welcome is presum'd,
Whose liberall Table's never unprepar'd,
Nor he of guests unfurnisht, of his meanes,
There's none can beare it with a braver port,
And keepe his state unshaken, one who sels not
Nor covets he to purchase, holds his owne
Without oppressing others, alwayes prest
To indeere to him any knowne Gentleman
In whom he finds good parts.

sp.speaker: Bantham.
sp.p: A Character not common in this age.

lg.l: I cannot wind him up
Vnto the least part of his noble worth.
Tis far above my strength.
See who comes yonder,
A fourth, to make us a full Messe of guests
At Master Generous Table.
Tush let him passe,
He is not worth our luring, a meere Coxcombe,
It is a way to call our wits in question,
To have him seene amongst us.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: He hath spy'd us, there is no way to evade him.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: That's my griefe; a most notorious lyar, out upon him.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Let's set the best face on't.

lg.l: What Gentlemen? all mine old acquaintance?
A whole triplicity of friends together? nay then
'Tis three to one we shall not soone part Company.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Dainty Mr. Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Delicate Master Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: You say right, Mr. Whetstone I have bin, Mr. Whetstone I am, and Mr. Whetstone I shall be, and those that know me, know withall that I have not my name for nothing, I am hee whom all the brave Blades of the Country use to whet their wits upon; sweet Mr. Shakton, dainty Mr. Bantham, and dainty Mr. Arthur, and how, and how, what all lustick, all froligozone? I know, you are going to my Vncles to dinner, and so am I too, What shall we all make one randevous there,
You need not doubt of your welcome.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: No doubt at all kind Mr. Whetstone; but we have not seene you of late, you are growne a great stranger amongst us, I desire sometimes to give you a visit; I pray where do you lye?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Where doe I lye? why sometimes in one place, and then againe in another, I love to shift lodgings; but most constantly, wheresoere I dine or sup, there doe I lye?

lg.l: I never heard that word proceed from him
I durst call truth till now.
But where so euer I lye 'tis no matter for that,
I pray you say, and say truth, are not you three now
Going to dinner to my Vncles?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: I thinke you are a Witch Master Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: How? A Witch Gentlemen? I hope you doe not meane to abuse me, though at this time (if report be true there are too many of them here in our Country) but I am sure I look like no such ugly Creature.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: It seemes then you are of opinion that there are Witches, for mine own part, I can hardly be induc'd to think there is any such kinde of people.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: No such kinde of people! I pray you tell me Gentlemen, did never any one of you know my Mother?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Why was your Mother a Witch?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I doe not say as Witches goe now a dayes, for they for the most part are ugly old Beldams, but she was a lusty young Lasse, and by her owne report, by her beauty and faire lookes bewitcht my Father.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: It seemes then your Mother was rather a yong wanton wench, than an old wither'd witch.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: You say right, and know withall I come of two ancient Families, for as I am a Whetstone by the Mother-side, so I am a By-blow by the Fathers.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It appeares then by your discourse, that you came in at the window.

lg.l: I would have you thinke I scorne like my Granams
Cat to leape over the Hatch.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: He hath confest himselfe to be a Bastard.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And I beleeve't as a notorious truth.

lg.l: Howsoever I was begot, here you see I am,
And if my Parents went to it without feare or wit,
What can I helpe it.
Very probable, for as he was got without feare,
So it is apparent he was borne without wit.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Gentlemen, it seemes you have some private businesse amongst your selves, which I am not willing to interrupt, I know not how the day goes with you, but for mine owne part, my stomacke is now much upon 12. You know what houre my Vncle keeeps, and I love ever to bee set before the first grace, I am going before, speake, shall I acquaint him with your comming after?

sp.speaker: Shak
sp.p: We meane this day to see what fare he keepes.

lg.l: And you know it is his custome to fare well,
And in that respect I think I may be his kinsman,
And so farewell Gentlemen, Ile be your fore-runner,
To give him notice of your visite.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And so intyre us to you.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Kind Mr. Byblow.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p:
I see you are perfect both in my name & sirname; I have bin ever bound unto you, for which I will at this time be your
Noverint, and give him notice that you Universi will bee with him per praesentes, and that I take to be presently.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Farewell As in praesenti.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: It seemes hee's peece of a Scholler.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What because he hath read a little Scriveners Latine, hee never proceeded farther in his Accidence than to Mentiri non est meum; and that was such a hard Lesson to learne, that he stucke at mentiri; and cu'd never reach to non est meum: since, a meere Ignaro, and not worth acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Are these then the best parts he can boast of?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: As you see him now, so shall you finde him ever: all in one strain, there is one only thing which I wonder he left our.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: And what might that be:

lg.l: Of the same affinity with the rest.
At every second word, he his commonly boasting
either of his Aunt or his Vncle.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You name him in good time, see where he comes.

lg.l: Gentlemen, Welcome, t'is a word I use,
From me expect no further complement:
Nor do I name it often at one meeting,
Once spoke (to those that understand me best,
And know I alwaies purpose as I speake)
Hath ever yet suffiz'd: so iet it you;
Nor doe I love that common phrase of guests,
As we make bold, or we are troublesome,
Wee take you unprovided, and the like;
I know you understanding Gentlemen,
And knowing me, cannot persuade your selves
With me you shall be troublesome or bold,
But still provided for my worthy friends,
Amongst whom you are lifted.
Noble sir, you generously instruct us, and to expresse
We can be your apt schollers: in a word
Wee come to dine with you.
And Gentlemen, such plainnesse doth best please me, I had notice
Of so much by my kinsman, and to show
How lovingly I tooke it, instantly
Rose from my chayre to meet you at the gate.
And be my selfe your usher; nor shall you finde
Being set to meat, that i'le excuse your fare,
Or say, I am sory it falls out so poore;
And had I knowne your comming wee'd have had
Such things and such, nor blame my Cooke, to say
This dish or that hath not bin sauc'st with care:
Words, fitting best a common Hostesse mouth,
When ther's perhaps some just cause of dislike
But not the table of a Gentleman;
Nor is it my wives custome; in a word, take what you find, & so
Sir without flattery
You may be call'd the sole surviving sonne
Of long since banisht Hospitality.
In that you please me not: But Gentlemen
I hope to be beholden unto you all,
Which if I proove, Ile be a gratefull debtor.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Wherein good sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: I ever studied plainenesse, and truth withall.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: I pray expresse your selfe.

lg.l: In few I shall. I know this youth to whom my wife is Aunt
Is (as you needs must finde him) weake and shallow:
Dull, as his name, and what for kindred sake
We note not, or at least, are loath to see,
Is unto such well-knowing Gentlemen
Most grossely visible: If for my sake
You will but seeme to winke at these his wants,
At least at table before us his friends,
I shall receive it as a courtesie
Not soone to be forgot.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Presume it sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Now when you please pray Enter Gentlemen.

lg.l: Would these my friends prepare the way before,
To be resolved of one thing before dinner
Would something adde unto mine appetite,
Shall I intreat you so much.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: O sir you may command us.

lg.l: I'th meane time
Prepare your stomackes with a bowle of Sacke.
My Cellar can affoord it; now Mr. Arthur
Pray freely speake your thoughts.
I come not sir
To presse a promise from you, tak't not so,
Rather to prompt your memory in a motion
Made to you not long since.
Wast not about
A Mannor, the best part of your estate,
Morgag'd to one slips no advantages
Which you would have redeem'd.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: True sir the same.

lg.l: And as I thinke, I promist at that time
To become bound with you, or if the usurer
(A base, yet the best title I can give him)
Perhaps should question that security,
To have the money ready. Wast not so?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It was to that purpose wee discourst.

lg.l: Provided, to have the Writings in my custody.
Else how should I secure mine owne estate.
To denie that I should appeare toth' World
Stupid, and of no braine.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Your monie's ready,

lg.l: And I remaine a man oblig'd to you.
Beyond all utterance.
Make then your word good
By speaking it no further, onely this,
It seemes your Vncle you trusted in so far
Hath failed your expectation.
Sir he hath, not that he is unwilling or unable.
But at this time unfit to be solicited;
For to the Countries wonder and my sorrow,
Hee is much to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Why I intreat you.

lg.l: Because hee's late become the sole discourse
Of all the countrey; for of a man respected
For his discretion and knowne gravitie,
As master of a govern'd Family,
The house (as if the ridge were fixt below,
And groundfils lifted up to make the roofe)
All now turn'd topsie turvy,

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Strange, but how?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.l: In such a retrograde & preposterous way
As seldome hath bin heard of. I thinke never.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Can you discourse the manner?

lg.l: The good man, in all obedience kneels vnto his son,
Hee with an austere brow commands his father.
The wife presumes not in the daughters sight
Without a prepared courtesie. The girle, shee
Expects it as a dutie; chides her mother
Who quakes and trembles at each word she speaks,
And what's as strange, the Maid she dominiers
O're her yong mistris, who is aw'd by her.
The son to whom the Father creeps and bends,
Stands in as much feare of the groome his man.
All in such rare disorder, that in some
As it breeds pitty, and in others wonder;
So in the most part laughter.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: How thinke you might this come.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: T'is thought by Witchcraft.

lg.l: They that thinke so dreame,
For my beliefe is, no such thing can be,
A madnesse you may call it: Dinner stayes;
That done, the best part of the afternoone
Wee'le spend about your businesse.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Nay but vnderstand me neighbor Doughty.

sp.speaker: Doughty.
sp.p: Good master Seely I do understand you, and over and over understand you so much, that I could e'ene blush at your fondnesse; and had I a sonne to serve mee so, I would conure a divell out of him.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Alas he is my childe.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: No, you are his childe to live in feare of him, indeed they say old men become children againe, but before I would become my childes childe, and make my foot my head, I would stand upon my head, and kick my heels at the sides.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: You do not know what an only son is, O see, he comes now if you can appease his anger toward me, you shall doe an act of timely charity.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.l: It is an office that I am but weakly versd in,
To plead to a sonne in the fathers behalfe,
Blesse me what lookes the devilish young Rascall

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I wonder at your confidence, and how you dare appeare before me.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A brave beginning.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: O sonne be patient.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: It is right reverend councell, I thanke you for it, I shall study patience shall I, while you practice waies to begger mee, shall I?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Very handsome.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: If ever I trangresse in the like againe—

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I have taken your word too often sir and neither can nor will forbeare you longer.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: What not your Father Mr. Gregory?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Whats that to you sir?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Pray tell me then sir, how many yeares has hee to serve you.

lg.l: What do you bring your spokesman now, your advocat,
What fee goes out of my estate now, for his Oratory?
Come I must tell you, you forget your selfe,
And in this foule unnaturall strife wherein
You trample on your father. You are falne
Below humanitie. Y'are so beneath
The title of a sonne, you cannot clayme
To be a man, and let me tell you were you mine
Thou shouldst not eat but on thy knees before me.
O this is not the way.
This is to raise Impatience into fury.
I do not seek his quiet for my ease,
I can beare all his chidings and his threats,
And take them well, very exceeding well,
And finde they do me good on my owne part,
Indeed they do reclaim me from those errors
That might impeach his fortunes, but I feare
Thunquiet strife within him hurts himselfe,
And wastes or weakens Nature, by the breach
Of moderate sleepe and dyet; and I can
No lesse than grieve to finde my weaknesses
To be the cause of his affliction,
And see the danger of his health and being.
Alas poore man? Can you stand open ey'd
Or dry ey'd either at this now in a Father?
Why, if it grieve you, you may look of ont,
I have seen more than this twice twenty times,
And have as often bin deceiv'd by his dissimulations
I can see nothing mended.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: He is a happy are that has brought vp his son to this.

lg.l: All shall be mended son content your selfe,
But this time forget but this last fault.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Yes, for a new one to morrow.

lg.l: Pray Mr. Gregory forget it, you see how
Submissive your poore penitent is, forget it,
Forget it, put it out o'your head, knocke it
Out of your braines. I protest, if my Father,
Nay if my fathers dogge should have sayd
As much to me, I should have embrac't him.
What was the trespasse? It c'ud not be so hainous.
Wel Sir, you now shall be a Iudge for all your jeering.
Was it a fatherly part thinke you having a sonne
To offer to enter in bonds for his nephew, so to indanger
My estate to redeeme his morgage.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: But I did it not sonne?

lg.l: I know it very well, but your dotage had done it,
If my care had not prevented it.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p:
Is that the businesse: why if he had done it, had hee not
bin sufficiently secur'd in having the morgage made over to himselfe.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: He does nothing but practice waies to undo himselfe, and me: a very spendthrift, a prodigall sire, hee was at the Ale but tother day, and spent a foure-penny club.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: 'Tis gone and past sonne.

lg.l: Can you hold your peace sir? And not long ago at the
Wine he spent his teaster, and two pence to the piper,
That was brave was it not?

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Truely we were civily merry. But I have left it.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Your civility have you not? For no longer agoe than last holiday evening he gam'd away eight double ring'd tokens on a rubbers at bowles with the Curate, and some of his idle companions.

lg.l: Fie Mr. Gregory Seely is this seemely in a sonne.
You'le have a rod for the childe your father shortly I feare.
Alasse did hee make it cry? Give me a stroke and Ile beat him,
Blesse me, they make me almost as mad as themselves.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: 'Twere good you would meddle with your own matters sir.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Sonne, sonne.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, as I am not beholden to you for house or Land, for it has stood in the name of my ancestry the Seelyes above two hundred yeares, so will I look you leave all as you found it.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: What is the matter con yeow tell?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: O Lawrence, welcom, Thou wilt make al wel I am sure.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Yie whick way con yeow tell, but what the foule evill doone yee, heres sick an a din.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Art thou his man fellow ha? that talkest thus to him?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Yie sir, and what ma' yoew o'that, he mainteynes me to rule him, and I'le deu't, or ma'the heart weary o'the weambe on him.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: This is quite upside downe, the sonne controlls the father, and the man overcrowes his masters coxscombe, sure they are all bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p:
'Twas but so, truely Lawrence; the peevish old man vex't me, for which I did my duty, in telling him his owne, and
Doughty here maintaines him against me.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: I forbodden yeow to meddle with the old carle, and let me alone with him, yet yeow still be at him, hee serv'd yeow but weell to bast ye for't, ant he were stronk enough, but an I saw foule with yee an I swaddle yee not savorly may my girts brast.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Prethee good Lawrence be gentle and do not fright thy Master so.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Yie, at your command anon.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Enough good Lawrence, you have said enough.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: How trow yeou that? A fine World when a man cannot be whyet at heame for busie brain'd neighbors.

lg.l: I know not what to say to any thing here,
This cannot be but witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I cannot indure it nor I will not indure it.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Hey day! the daughter upon the mother too.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: One of us two, chuse you which, must leave the house, wee are not to live together I see that, but I will know, if there be Law in Lancashire for't, which is fit first to depart the house or the World, the mother or the daughter.

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.p: Daughter I say.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Do you say the daughter, for that word I say the mother, unlesse you can prove me the eldest, as my discretion almost warrant it, I say the mother shall out of the house or take such courses in it as shall sort with such a house and such a daughter.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Daughter I say, I wil take any course so thou wilt leave thy passion; indeed it hurts thee childe, I'le sing and be merry, weare as fine clothes, and as delicate dressings as thou wilt have me, so thou wilt pacifie thy selfe, and be at peace with me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p:
O will yon so, in so doing I may chance to looke upon you. Is this a fit habite for a handsome young Gentlewomans mother, as I hope to be a Lady, you look like one o'the Scottish wayward sisters, O my hart has got the hickup, and all
lookes greene about me, a merry song now mother, and thou shalt be my white girle.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! she's overcome with joy at my conversion.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: She is most evidently bewitcht.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: There was a deft Lad and a Lasse fell in love,
with a fa la la, fa la la, Langtidowne dilly;
With kissing and toying this Maiden did prove,
with a fa la la, fa la la, Langtidowne dilly;
So wide i'th wast, and her Belly so high,
That unto her mother the Maiden did cry,
O Langtidowne dilly, O Langtidowne dilly,
fa la la Langtidowne, Langtidowne dilly.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Thus wodden yeou doone and I were dead, but while I live yoeu fadge not on it, is this aw the warke yeou confine?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Now comes the Mayd to set her Mistresses to work.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Nay pri'thee sweet Parnell, I was but chiding the old wife for her unhandsomnesse, and would have been at my work presently, she tels me now she will weare fine things, and I shall dresse her head as I list.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Here's a house well govern'd?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Dresse me no dressings, lessen I dresse yeou beth, and learne a new lesson with a wainon right now, han I bin a servant here this halfe dozen o'yeares, and con I fee yeou idler then my selve!

sp.speaker: Ioa. Win.
sp.p: Nay prithee sweet Parnell content, & hark thee—

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: I have knowne this, and till very lately, as well govern'd a Family as the Country yeilds, and now what a nest of severall humors it is growne, and all divellish ones, sure all the Witches in the Country, have their hands in this home-spun medley; and there be no few 'tis thought.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p:
Yie, yie, ye shall ye shall, another time, but not naw I thonke yeou, yeou shall as soone pisse and paddle in't, as slap me in the mouth with an awd Petticoat, or a new paire o
shoine, to be whyet, I cannot be whyet, nor I wonnot be whyet, to see sicky doings I.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Hold thy prattle Parnell, aw's com'd about as weene a had it, wotst thou what Parnell? wotst thou what? o deare, wotst thou what?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: What's the fond wexen waild trow I.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: We han bin in love these three yeares, and ever wee had not enough, now is it com'd about that our love shall be at an end for ever, and a day, for wee mun wed may hunny, we mun wed.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: What the Deowl ayles the lymmer lowne, bin thy braines broke lowse trow I.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Sick a waddin was there never i' Loncoshire as ween couple at on Monday newst.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Awa awaw, sayn yeou this sickerly, or done you but jaum me?

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: I jaum thee not nor flam thee not, 'tis all as true as booke, here's both our Masters have consented and concloyded, and our Mistresses mun yeild to yt, to put aw house and lond and aw they have into our hands.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Awa, awaw.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And we mun marry and be master and dame of aw.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Awa, awaw.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And theyn be our Sijourners, because they are weary of the world, to live in frendiblenesse, and see what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Awa, awaw, agone.

sp.speaker: Seel. & Greg.
sp.p: Nay 'tis true Parnell, here's both our hands on't, and give you joy.

sp.speaker: Ioan. & Win.
sp.p: And ours too, and 'twill be fine Ifackins.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw!

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Here's a mad businesse towards.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: I will bespeake the Guests.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And I the meat:

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: I'le dresse the dinner, though I drip my sweat.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: My care shall sumptuous parrelments provide.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And my best art shall trickly trim the Bride.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Ile get choyce musick for the merriment.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: And I will waite with wonder the event.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw.

div.head: ACTVS, II. SCAENA, I.

lg.l: HOe! well met, well met.
Meg. What new devise, what dainty straine
More for our myrth now then our gaine,
Shall we in practice put.
Nay dame,
Before we play another game.
We must a little laugh and thanke
Our feat familiars for the pranck
They playd us last.
Or they will misse
Vs in our next plot, if for this
They find not their reward.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: 'Tis right.

lg.l: Therefore sing Mawd, and call each spright.
Come away, and take thy duggy,

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: Come my Mamilion like a Puggy,

lg.l: And come my puckling take thy teat,
Your travels have deserv'd your meat.
Now upon the Churles ground
On which we're met, lets dance a round;
That Cocle, Darnell, Poppia wild,
May choake his graine, and fill the field.
Now spirits fly about the taske,
That we projected in our Maske.
Now let us laugh to thinke upon
The feat which we have so lately done,
In the distraction we have set
In Seelyes house; which shall beget
Wonder and sorrow 'mongst our foes,
Whilst we make laughter of their woes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

lg.l: I can but laugh now to foresee,
The fruits of their perplexity.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Of Seely's family?

lg.l: I, I, I, the Father to the Sonne doth cry,
The Sonne rebukes the Father old;
The Daughter at the mother Scold,
The wife the husband check and chide,
But that's no wonder, through the wide
World 'tis common.
But to be short,
The wedding must bring on the sport
Betwixt the hare-brayn'd man and mayd,
Master and dame that over-sway'd.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

lg.l: Enough, enough,
Our sides are charm'd, or else this stuffe
Would laughter-cracke them; let's away
About the Iig. we dance to day,
To spoyle the Hunters sport.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I that, be now the subject of our chat.

lg.l: Then list yee well, the Hunters are
This day by vow to kill a Hare,
Or else the sport they will forsweare;
And hang their Dogs up.
Stay, but where
Must the long threatned hare be found?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: They'l search in yonder Meadow ground.

lg.l: There will I be, and like a wily Wat,
Vntill they put me up; ile squat.
I and my puckling will a brace
Of Greyhounds be, fit for the race;
And linger where we may be tane
Vp for the course in the by-lane;
Then will we lead their Dogs a course,
And every man and every horse;
Vntill they breake their necks, and say—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Divell on Dun is rid this way. Ha. ha, ha, ha.

lg.l: All the doubt can be but this,
That if by chance of me they misse,
And start another Hare.
Then we'll not run
But finde some way how to be gone.
I shal know thee Peg, by thy grissel'd gut,
And I you Gilian by your gaunt thin gut.
But where will Mawd bestow her selfe today?

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: O' th' Steeple top; Ile sit & see you play.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Generous, Arthur, Bantam, Shakstone, and Whetstone.

lg.l: At meeting, and at parting Gentlemen,
I onely make use of that generall word,
So frequent at all feasts, and that but once; y'are welcome.
You are so, all of you, and I intreat you
Take notice of that speciall businesse,
Betwixt this Gentleman my friend, and I.
About the Morgage, to which writings drawne,
Your hands are witnesse.

sp.speaker: Baxt. & Shak.
sp.p: We acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: My hand is there too, for a man cannot set to his Marke, but it may be call'd his hand; I am a Gentleman both wayes, and it hath been held that it is the part of a Gentleman, to write a scurvie hand.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You write Sir like your selfe.

lg.l: Pray take no notice of his ignorance,
You know what I foretold you.
'Tis confest, but for that word by you so seldome spoke
By us so freely on your part perform'd,
We hold us much ingag'd.
I pray, no complement,
It is a thing I doe not use my selfe,
Nor doe I love 't in others.
For my part, could I at once dissolve my selfe to words
And after turne them into matter; such
And of that strength, as to attract the attention
Of all the curious, and most itching eares
Of this our Crittick age; it cou'd not make
A theame amounting to your noble worth:
You seeme to me to super-arrogate,
Supplying the defects of all your kindred
To innoble your own name: I now have done Sir.
Hey day, this Gentleman speakes likes a Country
Parson that had tooke his text out of Ovids Metamorphosis.
Sir, you Hyperbolize;
And I coo'd chide you for't, but whil'st you connive
At this my Kinsman, I shall winke at you;
'Twil prove an equall match.
Your name proclaimes
To be such as it speakes, you, Generous.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Still in that straine!

lg.l: Sir, sir, whilst you persever to be good
I must continue gratefull.
Gentlemen, the greatest part of this day you see is spent
In reading deeds, conveyances, and bonds,
With sealing and subscribing; will you now
Take part of a bad Supper.
We are like travellers
And where such bayt, they doe not use to Inne.
Our love and service to you.
The first I accept,
The Last I entertaine not, farewell Gentlemen.
We'l try if we can finde in our way home
When Hares come from their coverts, to reliffe,
A course or too.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Say you so Gentlemen, nay then I am for your company still, 'tis sayd Hares are like Hermophrodites, one while Male, and another Female, and that which begets this yeare, brings young ones the next; which some think to be the reason that witches take their shapes so oft: Nay if I lye Pliny lyes too, but come, now I have light upon you, I cannot so lightly leave you farewell Vnckle.

lg.l: Cozen I wish you would consort your selfe,
With such men ever, and make them your President,
For a more Gentile carriage.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Good Master Generous—

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Robin.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Goe call your Mistresse hither.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My Mistresse Sir, I doe call her Mistresse, as I doe call you Master, but if you would have me call my Mistresse to my Master, I may call lowd enough before she can heare me.

lg.l: Why she's not deafe I hope, I am sure since Dinner
She had her hearing perfect.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And so she may have at Supper too for ought I know, but I can assure you she is not now within my call.

lg.l: Sirrah you trifle, give me the Key oth' Stable,
I will goe see my Gelding; i' th' meane time
Goe seeke her out, say she shall finde me there.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: To tell you true sir, I shall neither finde my Mistresse here, nor you your Gelding there.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Ha! how comes that to passe?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Whilst you were busie about your writings, she came and commanded me to saddle your Beast, and sayd she would ride abroad to take the ayre.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Which of your fellowes did she take along to wayte on her?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: None sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: None! hath she us'd it often?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oftner I am sure then she goes to Church, and leave out Wednesdayes and Fridayes.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: And still alone?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If you call that alone, when no body rides in her company.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: But what times hath she sorted for these journeyes?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Commonly when you are abroad, and sometimes when you are full of businesse at home.

lg.l: To ride out often and alone, what sayth she
When she takes horse, and at her backe returne?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Onely conjures me that I shall keepe it from you, then clappes me in the fist with some small piece of silver, and then a
Fish cannot be more silent then I.

lg.l: I know her a good woman and well bred,
Of an unquestion'd carriage, well reputed
Amongst her neighbors, reckon'd with the best
And ore me most indulgent; though in many
Such things might breed a doubt and jealousie,
Yet I hatch no such phrensie. Yet to prevent
The smallest jarre that might betwixt us happen;
Give her no notice that I know thus much.
Besides I charge thee, when she craves him next
He be deny'd: if she be vext or mov'd
Doe not thou feare, Ile interpose my selfe
Betwixt thee and her anger, as you tender
Your duty and my service, see this done.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now you have exprest your minde, I know what I have to doe; first, not to tell her what I have told you &, next to keep her side-saddle from comming upon your Gueldings backe; but how soever it is like to hinder me of many a round tester.

lg.l: As oft as thou deny'st her, so oft clayme
That teaster from me, 't shall be roundly payd.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You say well in that sir, I dare take your word, you are an honest Gentleman, and my Master; and now take mine as I am your true servant, before she shall backe your Guelding again in your absence, while I have the charge of his keeping; she shall ride me, or Ile ride her.

lg.l: So much for that. Sirrah my Butler tels me
My Seller is drunke dry, I meane those Bottles
Of Sack and Claret, are all empty growne
And I have guests to morrow, my choyse friends.
Take the gray Nag i'th' stable, and those Bottles
Fill at Lancaster,
There where you use to fetch it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Good newes for me, I shall sir.

lg.l: O Robin, it comes short of that pure liquor
We drunke last Terme in London at the Myter
In Fleet-street, thou remembrest it; me thought
It was the very spirit of the Grape,
Meere quintessence of Wine.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes sir, I so remember it, that most certaine it is I never shal forget it, my mouth waters ever since when I but think on't, whilst you were at supper above, the drawer had me down into the Cellar below, I know the way in againe if I see't, but at that time to finde the way out againe, I had the help of more eies than mine owne: is the taste of that Ipsitate stil in your pallat sir?

lg.l: What then? But vaine are wishes, take those bottles
And see them fil'd where I command you sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I shall: never c'ud I have met with such a faire opportunitie: for iust in the mid way lies my sweet-heart, as lovely a lasse as any is in Lancashire, and kisses as sweetly: I'le see her going or comming, i'le have one smouch at thy lips, and bee with thee to bring Mal Spencer.

lg.l: Go hasten your return, what he hath told me
Touching my wife is somewhat strange, no matter
Bee't as it will, it shall not trouble me.
Shee hath not lyen so long so neere my side,
That now I should be jealous.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: You seeme sir a Gentleman of quality, and no doubt but in your youth have beene acquainted with affaires military, in your very lookes there appeares bounty, and in your person humanity. Please you to vouchsafe the tender of some small courtesie to help to beare a souldier into his countrey.

lg.l: Though I could tax you friend, & justly too
For begging 'gainst the Statute in that name,
Yet I have ever bin of that compassion,
Where I see want, rather to pittie it
Than to use power. Where hast thou serv'd?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: With the Russian against the Polack, a heavy war, and hath brought me to this hard fate. I was tooke prisoner by the Pole, & after some few weeks of durance, got both my freedom and passe. I have it about me to show, please you to vouchsafe the perusall.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: It shall not need. What Countreyman.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: Yorkeshire sir. Many a sharp battell by land, and many a sharpe storme at sea, many a long mile, and many a short meale, I have travel'd and suffer'd ere I c'ud reach thus far, I beseech you sir take my poore & wretched case into your worships noble consideration.

lg.l: Perhaps thou lov'st this wandring life
To be an idle loitering begger, than
To eat of thine owne labour.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: I sir! Loitering I defie sir, I hate lazinesse as I do leprosie: It is the next way to breed the scurvie, put mee to hedge, ditch, plow, thresh, dig, delve, any thing: your worship shal find that I love nothing lesse than loitering.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Friend thou speakest well.

div.stage: Enter Miller (his hands and face scratcht, and bloudy.

sp.speaker: Miller.
sp.p: Your Mill quoth he, if ever you take me in your mill againe, i'le give you leave to cast my flesh to the dogges, and grinde my flesh to pouder, betwixt the Milstones. Cats do you call them, for their hugenesse they might bee cat a mountaines, and for their clawes, I thinke I have it here in red and white to show, I pray looke here sir, a murreine take them, ile be sworne they have scratcht, where I am sure it itcht not.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: How cam'st thou in this pickle?

sp.speaker: Ml.
sp.p: Yoiu see sir, and what you see, I have felt, & am come to give you to understand I'le not indure such another night if you would give mee your mill for nothing, they say we Millers are theeves: but I c'ud as soone bee hangd as steale one piece of a nap all the night long, good Landlord provide your selfe of a new tenant, the noise of such catterwawling, & such scratching and clawing, before I would indure againe, i'le bee tyed to the saile when the winde blowes sharpest, and they flie swiftest, till I be torne into as many fitters as I have toes and fingers.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: I was a Miller my selfe before I was a souldier. What one of my own trade should be so poorely spirited frighted with cats?

lg.l: Sir trust me with the Mill that he forsakes.
Here is a blade that hangs upon this belt
That spight of all these Rats, Cats, Wezells, Witches
Or Dogges, or Divels, Shall so coniure them
I'le quiet my possession.
Well spoke Souldier.
I like thy resolution. Fellow, you then
Have given the Mill quite over.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Over and over, here I utterly renounce it; nor would I stay in it longer, if you would give me your whole estate; nay if I say it, you may take my word Landlord.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: I pray sir dare you trust your mill with me.

lg.l: I dare, but I am loth, my reasons these.
For many moneths, scarce any one hath lien there
But have bin strangely frighted in his sleepe,
Or from his warme bed drawne into the floore,
Or clawd and scratcht, as thou seest this poore man,
So much, that it stood long untenanted,
Till he late undertooke it, now thine eies
Witnesse how he hath sped.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: Give me the keies, ile stand it all danger.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: 'Tis a match: deliver them.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Mary with all my heart, and I am glad, I am so rid of em.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now I have gathered Bullies, and fild my bellie pretty well, i'le goe see some sport. There are gentlemen coursing in the medow hard by; and 'tis a game that I love better than going to Schoole ten to one.
sp.stage: Enter an invisible spirit. I. Adson with a brace of grey-hounds.
sp.p:
What have we here a brace of Greyhounds broke loose from their masters: it must needs be so, for they have both their Collers and slippes about their neckes. Now I looke better upon them, me thinks I should know them, and so I do: these are Mr. Robinsons dogges, that dwels some two miles off, i'le take them up, & lead them home to their master; it may be somthing in my way, for he is as liberall a gentleman, as any is in our countrie, Come Hector, come. Now if I c'ud but start a Hare by the way, kill her, and carry her home to my supper, I should thinke I had
made a better afternoones worke of it than gathering of bullies. Come poore curres along with me.

div.stage: Enter Arthur, Bantam, Shakstone, and Whestone.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: My Dog as yours.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A piece.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: I say the pide dog shall outstrip the browne.

sp.speaker: Whe.
sp.p: And ile take the brown dogs part against the pide

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Yes when hee's at his lap youle take his part.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Bantam forbeare him prethee.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: He talks so like an Asse I have not patience to indure his non sence.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: The browne dogge for two peeces.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Of what?

lg.l: Of what you dare; name them from the last
Farthings with the double rings, to the late
Coy'nd peeces which they say are all counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Well sir, I take ●ou: will you cover these, give them into the hands of either of those two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: What needs that? doe you thinke my word and my money is not all one?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And weigh alike: both many graines too light.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Enough of that, I presume Mr. Whetstone, you are not ignorant what belongs to the sport of hunting.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I thinke I have reason, for I have bin at the death of more Hares.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: More then you shed the last fall of the leafe.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: More then any man here I am sure. I should be loath at these yeares to be ignorant of hairing or whoring. I know a hare close hunted, clime a tree.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: To finde out birds nests

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Another leap into a river, nothing appearing above water, save onely the tip of her nose to take breath.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Nay that's verie likely, for no man can fish with an angle but his Line must be made of hare.

lg.l: You say right, I know another, who to escape the
Dogges hath taken a house, and leapt in at a window.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: It is thought you came into the World that way.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: How meane you that?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Because you are a bastard.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Bastard! O base.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And thou art base all over.

lg.l: Needs must I now condemne your indiscretion,
To set your wit against his.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Bastard? that shall be tried; well Gentlemen concerning Hare-hunting you might have hard more, if he had had the grace to have said lesse, but for the word Bastard, if I do not tell my Vncle, I and my Aunt too, either when I would speake ought or goe of the skore for any thing, let me never be trusted, they are older than I, and what know I, but they might bee by when I was begot; but if thou Bantam do'st not heare of this with both thine eares, if thou hast them still, and not lost them by scribling, instead of Whet-stone call me Grinde-stone, and for By-blow, Bulfinch. Gentlemen, for two of you your companie is faire and honest; but for you Bantam, remember and take notice also, that I am a bastard, and so much i'le testifie to my Aunt and Vncle.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What have you done, 'twill grieve the good old Gentleman, to heare him baffled thus.

lg.l: I was in a cold sweat ready to faint
The time he staid amongst us.

sp.speaker: Shak.

lg.l: But come, now the Hare is found and started,
She shall have Law, so to our sport.

sp.p:
A Hare, a Hare, halloe, halloe, the Divell take these curres, will they not stir, halloe, halloe, there, there, there, what are they growne so lither and so lazie? Are Mr. Robinsons dogges turn'd tykes with a wanion? the Hare is yet in sight, halloe, halloe, mary hang you for a couple of mungrils (if you were worth hanging, & have you serv'd me thus? nay then Ile serve you with the like sauce, you shall to the next bush, there will I tie you, and use you like a couple of curs as you are, & though not lash you, yet
lash you whilest my switch will hold, nay since you have left your speed, ile see if I can put spirit into you, and put you in remembrance what halloe, halloe meanes.
sp.stage: As he beats them, there appeares before him, Gooddy Dickison, and the Boy upon the dogs, going in.
sp.p: Now blesse me heaven, one of the Greyhounds turn'd into a woman, the other into a boy! The lad I never saw before, but her I know well; it is my gammer Dickison.

lg.l: Sirah, you have serv'd me well to swindge me thus.
You yong rogue, you have vs'd me like a dog.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: When you had put your self into a dogs skin, I pray how c'ud I help it; but gammer are not you a Witch? if you bee, I beg upon my knees you will not hurt me.

lg.l: Stand up my boie, for thou shalt have no harme,
Be silent, speake of nothing thou hast seene.
And here's a shilling for thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ile have none of your money gammer, because you are a Witch: and now she is out of her foure leg'd shape, ile see if with my two legs I can out-run her.

sp.speaker: Dickis.
sp.p: Nay sirra, though you be yong, and I old, you are not so nimble, nor I so lame, but I can overtake you.

lg.l: But Gammer what do you meane to do with me
Now you have me?
To hugge thee, stroke thee, and embrace thee thus,
And teach thee twentie thousand prety things.
So thou tell no tales; and boy this night
Thou must along with me to a brave feast.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not I gammer indeed la, I dare not stay ont late, My father is a fell man, and if I bee out long, will both chide and beat me.

lg.l: Not sirra, then perforce thou shalt along,
This bridle helps me still at need,
And shall provide us of a steed.
Now sirra, take your shape and be
Prepar'd to hurrie him and me.
Now looke and tell mee wher's the lad become.
The boy is vanisht, and I can see nothing in his stead
But a white horse redie sadled and bridled.

sp.speaker: Dickis.

lg.l: And thats the horse we must bestride,
On which both thou and I must ride,
Thou boy before and I behinde,
The earth we tread not, but the winde,
For we must progresse through the aire,
And I will bring thee to such fare
As thou ne're saw'st, up and away,
For now no longer we can stay.

sp.stage: She catches him up, & turning round. Exit

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Help, help.
Thanks my sweet Mall for thy courteous entertainment, thy creame, thy cheese-cakes, and every good thing, this, this, & this for all.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But why in such hast good Robin?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I confesse my stay with thee is sweet to mee, but I must spur Cutt the faster for't, to be at home in the morning, I have yet to Lancaster to ride to night, and this my bandileer of bottles, to fill to night, and then halfe a score mile to ride by currie-combe time, i'the morning, or the old man chides Mal.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Hee shall not chide thee, feare it not.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Pray Bacchus I may please him with his wine, which will be the hardest thing to do; for since hee was last at London and tasted the Divinitie of the Miter, scarce any liquour in Lancashire will go downe with him, sure, sure he will never be a Puritane, he holds so well with the Miter.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well Robert, I find your love by your haste from me, ile undertake you shal be at Lancaster, & twise as far, & yet at home time enough, and be rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thou art a witty rogue, and thinkst to make me believe any thing, because I saw thee make thy broome sweepe the house without hands t'other day.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You shall see more than that presently, because you shall beleeve me; you know the house is all a bed here: and I dare not be mist in the morning. Besides, I must be at the wedding of Lawrence and Parnell to morrow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I your old sweet heart Lawrence? Old love will not be forgotten

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I care not for the losse of him, but if I fit him not hang me: but to the point, if I goe with you to night, and help you to as good wine as your master desires, and you keepe your time with him, you will give me a pinte for my company.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thy belly full wench.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I'le but take up my milk payle and leave it in the field, till our comming backe in the morning, and wee'll away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Goe fetch it quickly then.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No Robert, rather than leave your company so long, it shall come to me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I would but see that.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Looke yonder, what do you thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Light, it comes; and I do thinke there is so much of the Divell in't as will turne all the milke shall come in't these seven yeares, and make it burne too, till it stinke worse than the Proverbe of the Bishops foot.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Looke you sir, heere I have it, will you get up and away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My horse is gone, nay prithee Mal. thou hast set him away, leave thy Roguerie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Looke againe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: There stands a blacke long-sided jade: mine was a truss'd gray.

lg.l: Yours was too short to carrie double such a journey.
Get up I say, you shall have your owne againe i'th morning.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay but, nay but.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay, and you stand butting now, i'le leave you to look your horse. Payle on afore to the field, and staie till I come.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Come away then, hey for Lancaster: stand up.

div.head: ACTVS, III. SCENA, I.
div.stage: Enter old Seely and Ióane his Wife.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: COme away wife, come away, and let us be ready to breake the Cake over the Brides head at her entrance; we will have the honour of it, we that have playd the Steward and Cooke at home, though we lost Church by't, and saw not Parson Knit-knot doe his office, but wee shall see all the house rites perform'd; and.— oh what a day of jollity and tranquility is here towards?

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.p: You are so frolick and so cranck now, upon the truce is taken amongst us, because our wrangling shall not wrong the Wedding, but take heed (you were best) how ye behave your selfe, lest a day to come may pay for all.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: I feare nothing, and I hope to dye in this humor.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Oh how hot am I! rather then I would dresse such another dinner this twelve moneth, I would wish Wedding quite out of this yeares Almanack.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Ile fetch a Cup of Sack Wife—

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: How brag he is of his liberty, but the holy day carries it.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Here, here sweet-heart, they are lóng me thinks a comming, the Bels have rung out this halfe houre, harke now the wind brings the sound of them sweetly againe.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: They ring backwards me thinks.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: I fack they doe, sure the greatest fire in the Parish is in our Kitchin, and there's no harme done yet, no 'tis some merry conceit of the stretch-ropes the Ringers, now they have done, and now the Wedding comes, hearke, the Fidlers and all, now have I liv'd to see a day, come, take our stand, and be ready for the Bride-cake, which we will so cracke and crumble upon her crowne: o they come, they come.

div.stage: Enter Musitiane, Lawrence, Parnell, Win. Mal. Spencer, two Country Lasses Doughty, Greg. Arthur, Shakton, Bantam, and Whetstone.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ioy, health; and children to the married paire.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: & Parn. We thanke you all.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: So pray come in and fare.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: As well as we and taste of every cate:

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: With bonny Bridegroome and his love mate.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: This begins bravely.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: They agree better then the Bels eene now, 'slid they sung tunably till we were all out of the Church, and then they clatter'd as the divell had beene in the Bellfry: on in the name of Wedlocke, Fidlers on.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: On with your melody.

lg.l: Enter the Gates with joy,
And as you enter play the sack of Troy.

div.stage: The Fidlers passe through, and play the battle.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Welcome Bride Parnell.

sp.speaker: Seel.

lg.l: Bridegroome Lawrence eke,
In you before, for we this cake must breake.
Over the Bride—
Forgi' me- what's become
O' th' Cake wife!

sp.stage: As they lift up the Cake, the Spirit snatches it, and powres down bran.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: It slipt out of my hand, and is falne into crums I think.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Crums? the divell of crum is here, but bran; nothing but bran, what prodigie is this?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Is my best Brides Cake come to this! o wea warth it.

div.stage: Exit Parn Seely, Joane, and Maides.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: How daintily the Brides haire is powder'd with it.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: My haire stands an end to see it.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: I was never so amaz'd!

sp.speaker: Dougb.
sp.p: What can it meane?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Pax, I think not on't, 'tis but some of my Father and Mothers roguery, this is a Law-day with 'em, to doe what they list.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I never feare any thing, so long as my Aunt has but bidden me thinke of her, and she'll warrant me.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, let's follow the rest in, and feare nothing yet, the house smels well of good cheere.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Gentlemen, will it please you draw neere, the guests are now all come, and the house almost full, meat's taken up.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: We were now comming.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: But sonne Gregory, Nephew Arthur, and the rest of the young Gentlemen, I shall take it for a favor if you will (it is an office which very good Gentlemen doe in this Country) accompane the Bridegroome in serving the meat.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Nay neighbor Doughty, your yeares shall excuse you.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Peugh, I am not so old but I can carry more meate then I can eate, if the young rascals coo'd carry their drinke as well, the Country would be quieter—

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Well fare your hearts,— the dresser calls in Gentlemen,

'Tis a busie time, yet will I review the Bill of fare, for this dayes dinner— (Reades) for 40. people of the best quality, 4. messes of meat; viz. a leg of Mutton in plum-broth, a dish of Marrow-bones, a Capon in white-broth, a Surlovne of beefe, a Pig, a Goose, a Turkie, and two Pyes: for the second course, to every messe 4. Chickens in a dish, a couple of Rabbets, Custard, Flawn, Florentines, and stewd pruines,— all very good Country fare, and for my credit,—
sp.stage: Enter Musitians playing before, Lawrence, Doughty, Arthur, Shakton Bantam, Whetstone, and Gregory, with dishes: A Spirit (over the doore) does some action to the dishes as they enter.
sp.p: The service enters, O well sayd Musicke, play up the meat to the Table till all be serv'd in, Ile see it passe in answer to my bill.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Hold up your head Mr. Bridegroome.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: On afore Fidlers, my double cewles in my honds.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Inprime, a leg of Mutton in plum-broth,— how now Mr. Bridegroome, what carry you?

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: 'Twere hot eene now, but now it's caw'd as a stoane.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: A stone, 'tis horne man.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Aw—

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: It was Mutton, but now 'tis the horns on't.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Aw where's my Bride—

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: 'Zookes, I brought as good a Surloyne of Beefe from the Dresser as Knife coo'd be put to, and see— Ile stay i' this house no longer.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And if this were not a Capon in white broth, I am one i' the Coope.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: All, all's transform'd, looke you what I have!

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: And I! Yet I feare nothing thank my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I had a Pie that is not open'd yet, Ile see what's in that— live Birds as true as I live, look where they flye!

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Witches, live Witches, the house is full of witches, if we love our lives let's out on't.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: O husband, O guests, O sonne, O Gentlemen, such a chance in a Kitchin was never heard of, all the meat is flowne out o' the chimney top I thinke, and nothing instead of it, but Snakes, Bates, Frogs, Beetles, Hornets, and Humble-bees; all the Sallets are turn'd to Iewes-eares, Mushromes, and Puck fists; and all the Custards into Cow sheards!

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: What shall we doe, dare we stay any longer?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Dare we! why not, I defie all Witches, and all their workes; their power on our meat, cannot reach our persons.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I say so too, and so my Aunt ever told me, so long I will feare nothing; be not afrayd Mr. Doughty.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Zookes, I feare nothing living that I can see more then you, and that's nothing at all, but to thinke of these invisible mischiefes, troubles me I confesse.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Sir I will not goe about to over-rule your reason, but
but for my part I will not out of a house on a Bridall day, till I see the last man borne.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Zookes thou art so brave a fellow that I will stick to thee, and if we come off handsomely, I am an old Batchelour thou know'st, and must have an heyre, I like thy spirit, where's the Bride? where's the Bridegroome? where's the Musicke? where be the Lasses? ha' you any wine i' the house, though we make no dinner, lets try if we can make an afternoone.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Nay sir if you please to stay, now that the many are frighted away, I have some good cold meates, and halfe a dozen bottles of Wine.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: And I will bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Say you me so, but will not your sonne be angry, and your daughter chide you.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Feare not you that sir, for look you I obey my Father.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And I my Mother.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: And we are all at this instant as well and as sensible of our former errors, as you can wish us to be.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Na, if the Witches have but rob'd of your meat, and restor'd your reason, here has beene no hurt done to day, but this is strange, and as great a wonder as the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It seemes though these Hags had power to make the Wedding cheere a Deceptio visus, the former store has scap'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: I am glad on't, but the divell good 'hem with my Surloyne, I thought to have set that by mine owne Trencher— But you have cold meat you say?

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: And Wine you say?

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: I hope the Country wenches and the Fidlers are not gone.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: They are all here, and one the merriest Wench; that makes all the rest so laugh and tickle.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Gentlemen will you in?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed on all parts.

sp.speaker: Dought,
sp.p: If not a Wedding we will make a Wake on't, and away with the Witch; I feare nothing now you have your wits againe: but look you, hold 'em while you have 'em.

div.stage: Enter Generous, and Robin, with a Paper.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: I confesse thou hast done a Wonder in fetching me so good Wine, but my good Servant Robert, goe not about to put a Myracle upon me, I will rather beleeve that Lancaster affords this Wine, which I thought impossible till I tasted it, then that thou coo'dst in one night fetch it from London.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I have known when you have held mee for an honest fellow, and would have beleev'd me.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Th' art a Knave to wish me to beleeve this, forgime, I would have sworne if thou had'st stayd but time answerable for the journey (to his that flew to Paris and back to London in a day) it had been the same Wine, but it can never fall within the compasse of a Christians beleefe, that thou cou'dst ride above three hundred miles in 8. houres: You were no longer out, and upon one Horse too, and in the Night too!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And carry a Wench behind me too, and did something else too, but I must not speak of her lest I be divell-torne.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: And fill thy bottles too, and come home halfe drunke too, for so thou art, thou wouldst never a had such a fancy else!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am sorry I have sayd so much, and not let Lancaster have the credit o' the Wine.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: O are you so! and why have you abus'd me and your selfe then all this while, to glorifie the Myter in Fleet-street?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I could say sir, that you might have the better opinion of the Wine, for there are a great many pallats in the Kingdome that can relish no Wine, unlesse it be of such a Taverne, and drawne by such a Drawer—

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I sayd, and I say againe, if I were within ten mile of London, I durst sweare that this was Myter Wine, and drawn by honest Iacke Paine.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay then sir I swore, and I sweare againe, honest Iack Paine drew it.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, if I coo'd beleeve there were such a thing as Witchcraft, I should thinke this slave were bewitch'd now with an opinion.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Much good doe you sir, your Wine and your mirth, and my place for your next Groome, I desire not to stay to be laught out of my opinion.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Nay be not angry Robin, we must not part so, and how does my honest Drawer? ha, ha, ha; and what newes at London, Robin? ha, ha, ha; but your stay was so short I think you coo'd heare none, and such your haste home that you coo'd make none: is't not so Robin? ha, ha, ha, what a strange fancy has good Wine begot in his head?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now will I push him over and over with a peece of paper: Yes sir, I have brought you something from London.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Come on, now let me heare.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Your honest Drawer sir, considering that you consider'd him well for his good wine—

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What shall we heare now?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Was very carefull to keepe or convay this paper to you, which it seemes you dropt in the roome there.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Blesse me! this paper belongs to me indeed, 'tis an acquittance, and all I have to show for the payment of one hundred pound, I tooke great care for't, and coo'd not imagine where or how I might loose it, but why may not this bee a tricke? this Knave may finde it when I lost it, and conceale it till now to come over me withall. I will not trouble my thoughts with it further at this time, well Robin looke to your businesse, and have a care of my Guelding.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yes Sir. I think I have netled him now, but not as I was netled last night, three hundred Miles a Night upon a Rawbon'd Divell, as in my heart it was a Divell, and then a Wench that shar'd more o' my backe then the sayd Divell did o' my Bum, this is ranke riding my Masters: but why had I such an itch to tell my Master of it, and that he should beleeve it; I doe now wish that I had not told, and that hee will not beleeve it, for I dare not tell him the meanes: 'Sfoot my Wench and her friends the Fiends, will teare me to pieces if I discover her; a notable rogue, she's at the Wedding now, for as good a Mayd as the best o'em— O my Mistresse.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Generous, with a Bridle.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Robin.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Quickly good Robin, the gray Guelding.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What other horse you please Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And why not that?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Truly Mistresse pray pardon me, I must be plaine with you, I dare not deliver him you; my master has tane notice of the ill case you have brought him home in divers times.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: O is it so, and must he be made acquainted with my actions by you, and must I then be controll'd by him, and now by you; you are a sawcey Groome.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You may say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: No sir, Ile doe my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Aw.

lg.l: Horse, horse, see thou be,
And where I point thee carry me.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Was there ever such a medley of mirth, madnesse, and drunkennesse, shuffled together.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Thy Vnckle and Aunt, old Mr. Seely and his wife, doe nothing but kisse and play together like Monkeyes.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes, they doe over-love one another now.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And young Gregory and his sister doe as much overdoe their obedience now to their Parents.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And their Parents as much over-doat upon them, they are all as farre beyond their wits now in loving one another, as they were wide of them before in crossing.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Yet this is the better madnesse.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: But the married couple that are both so daintily whitled, that now they are both mad to be a bed before Supper-time, and by and by he will, and she wo' not; streight she will and he wo' not, the next minute they both forget they are married, and defie one another.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: My sides eene ake with laughter.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p:
But the best sport of all is, the old Batchelour Master
Doughty, that was so cautious, & feat'd every thing to be witchcraft, is now wound up to such a confidence that there is no such thing, that hee dares the Divell doe his worst, and will not out o'the house by all persuasion, and all for the love of the husbandmans daughter within, Mal Spencer.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: There I am in some danger, he put me into halfe a beliefe I shall be his heire, pray love shee be not a witch to charme his love from mee. Of what condition is that wench do'st thou know her?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: A little, but Whetstone knowes her better.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Hang him rogue, he'le belye her, and speak better than she deserves, for he's is love with her too. I saw old Doughty give him a box o'the eare for kissing her, and hee turnd about as he did by thee yesterday, and swore his Aunt should know it.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Who would ha'thought that impudent rogue would have come among us after such a baffle.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: He told me, hee had complain'd to his Aunt on us, and that she would speak with us.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Wee will all to her to patch vp the businesse, for the respect I beare her husband, noble Generous.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Here he comes.

lg.l: Hearke you Mr. Byblow do you know the lasse within?
What do you call her, Mal Spencer?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Sir, what I know i'le keepe to my selfe, a good civile merry harmlesse rogue she is, and comes to my Aunt often, and thats all I know by her.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: You doe well to keepe it to your selfe sir.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: And you may do well to question her if you dare. For the testy old coxcombe that will not let her goe out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Take heed, he's at your heels.

div.stage: Enter Doughty, Mal, two countrey Lasses

lg.l: Come away Wenches, where are you Gentlemen?
Play Fidlers: lets have a dance, ha my little rogue.
Zookes what ayles thy nose.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My nose! Nothing sir.— turnes about— Yet mee thought a flie toucht it. Did you see any thing?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: No, no, yet I would almost ha' sworn, I would not have sprite or goblin blast thy face, for all their kingdome. But hangt there is no such thing: Fidlers will you play?
Gentlemen will you dance?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.l: This Family of love? Let's have them into the revels.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Hold a little then.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: O Father twentie times a day is too little to aske you blessing.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Goe too you are a rascall: and you houswife teach your daughter better manners: i'le ship you all for new England els.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: The knot's untied, and this is another change.

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.p: Yes I will teach her manners, or put her out to spin two penny tow: so you deare husband will but take mee into favor: i'le talke with you dame when the strangers are gone.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Deare Father.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Deare Mother.

sp.speaker: Greg. Win.
sp.p: Deare Father and Mother pardon us but this time.

sp.speaker: See. Ioa.
sp.p: Never, and therefore hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Nay thats unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Greg. Win.
sp.p: Oh!— Weepe.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: But for your sake i'le forbeare them, and beare with any thing this day.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Doe you note this? Now they are all worse then ever they were, in a contrary vaine: What thinke you of Witchcraft now?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: They are all naturall fooles man, I finde it now.
Art thou mad to dreame of Witchcraft?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: He's as much chang'd and bewitcht as they I feare.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Hey day! Here comes the payre of boyld Lovers in Sorrell sops.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Nay deare hunny, nay hunny, but eance, eance.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Na, na, I han' swarne, I han' swarne, not a bit afore bed, and look yeou it's but now dauncing time.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Come away Bridegroome, wee'll stay your stomack with a daunce. Now masters play a good: come my Lasse wee'l shew them how 'tis

div.stage: As they beginne to daunce, they play another tune, then fall into many.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ban. Sha.
sp.p: Whether now, hoe?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Hey day! why you rogues.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: What do's the Divell ride o' your Fiddlestickes.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: You drunken rogues, hold, hold, I say, and begin againe soberly the beginning of the World

div.stage: Musicke. Every one a severall tune.

sp.speaker: Arth. Bant. Shak
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, How's this?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Every one a severall tune

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: This is something towards it. I bad them play the beginning o' the World, and they play, I know not what.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No 'tis running o' the country severall waies.
But what do you thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Dough
sp.p: Thinke! I thinke they are drunke Prithee doe not thou thinke of Witchcraft; for my part, I shall as soone thinke this maid one, as that theres any in Lancashire.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Why do'st thou laugh?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To thinke this Bridegroome should once ha'bin mine, but he shall rue it, ile hold him this point on't, and thats all I care for him.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: A witty Rogue.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I tell you sir, they say shee made a payle follow her t'other day up two payre of stayres.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: You lying Rascall.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: O sir forget your anger.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Looke you Mr. Bridegroome, what my care provides for you

sp.speaker: Lawrence.
sp.p: What, a point?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes put it in your pocket it may stand you instead anon, when all your points be tane away, to trusse up your trinkits, I meane your slopes withall.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Mal for awd acquaintance I will ma' thy point a point of preferment. It shan bee the Foreman of a haell Iewrie o'points, and right here will I weare it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Wy'a, wy'a, awd leove wo no be forgetten, but ay's never be jealous the mare for that.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Play fidlers any thing.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: I, and lets see your faces, that you play fairely with us.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: We do sir, as loud as we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Play out that we may heare you.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: So we do sir, as loud as we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Doe you heare any thing?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Nothing not we sir.

lg.l: 'Tis so, the rogues are brib'd to crosse me,
And their Fiddles shall suffer, I will breake em as small as the
Bride cake was to day.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Looke you sir, they'l save you a labour, they are doing it themselves.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Oh brave Fidlers, there was never better scuffling for the Tudberry Bull.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This is mother Iohnson and Gooddy Dickisons roguerie, I finde it but I cannot helpe it, yet I will have musicke: sir theres a Piper withour, would be glad to earne money.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: She has spoke to purpose, & whether this were witchcraft or not: I have heard my Aunt say twentie times, that no Witchcraft can take hold of a Lancashire Bag-pipe, for it selfe is able to charme the Devell, ile fetch him.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p:
Well said, a good boy nów; come bride and bridegroome, leave your kissing and fooling, and prepare to come into the daunce. Wee'le have a Horne-pipe, and then a posset and
to bed when you please. Welcome Piper, blow till thy bagge cracke agen, a lusty Horne-pipe, and all into the daunce, nay young and old.

div.stage: Daunce. Lawrence and Parnell reele in the daunce. At the end, Mal vanishes, & the piper.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravely performd.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Stay, wheres my lasse?

sp.speaker: Arth. Ban. Shak
sp.p: Vanisht, she and the Piper both vanisht, no bodie knowes how.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Now do I plainly perceive again, here has bin nothing but witcherie all this day; therfore into your posset, & agree among your selves as you can, ile out o'the house. And Gentlemen, if you love me or your selves, follow me.

sp.speaker: Ar. Bant. Sha. Whet.
sp.p: I, I, Away, away.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Now good son, wife, and daughter, let me intreat you be not angry.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: O you are a trim mother are you not?

sp.speaker: Ioa.
sp.p: Indeed childe, ile do so no more.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Now sir, i'le talke with you, your champions are al gon.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Weell sir, and what wun yeou deow than?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Whay, whay, whats here to doe? Come awaw, and whickly, and see us into our Brayd Chember, & delicatly ludgd togeder, or wee'l whap you out o'dores ith morne to sijourne in the common, come away.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Wee follow yee.

div.head: ACTVS, IIII. SCAENA, I.
div.p: KNow you this gingling bridle, if you see't agen? I wanted but a paire of gingling spurs to make you mend your pace, and put you into a sweat.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p:
Yes, I have reason to know it after my
hard journey, they say there be light women, but for your owne part, though you be merry. Yet I may be sorry for your heavinesse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gener.
sp.p: I see thou art not quite tyr'd by shaking of thy selfe, 'tis a signe that as thou hast brought mee hither, so thou art able to beare mee backe, and so you are like good Robert. You will not let me have your masters gelding, you will not. Wel fir, as you like this journey, so deny him to me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You say well mistresse, you have jaded me (a pox take you for a jade.) Now I bethinke my selfe how damnably did I ride last night, and how divellishly have I bin rid now.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Doe you grumble you groome? Now the bridl's of, I turne thee to grazing gramercy my good horse, I have no better provender for thee at this time, thou hadst best like Aesops Asse to feed upon Thistles, of which this place will affoord thee plenty. I am bid to a better banquet, which done, ile take thee up from grasse, spur cutt, and take a short cutt home. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A pox upon your tayle.

div.stage: Enter all the Witches and Mal, at severall dores.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Lady of the feast is come, welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Is all the cheare that was prepared to grace the wedding feast, yet come?

lg.l: part of it's here.
The other we must pull for. But whats hee?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: My horse, my horse, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
My horse, my horse, I would I were now some country Major, and in authority, to see if I would not venter to rowze your Satanicall sisterhood: Horse, horse, see thou be, & where I point thee, carry me: is that the trick on't? the divel himselfe shall be her carrier next if I can shun her: & yet my Mr. will not beleeve theres any witches: theres no running away; for I neither know how nor whether, besides to my thinking, theres a deepe ditch, & a hye quick-set about mee, how shall I passe the time? What place is this? it looks like an old barne: ile peep in at some cranny or other, and try if I can see what they are doing. Such a bevy of beldames did I never behold; and cramming
like so many Cormorants: Marry choke you with a mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickison.
sp.p: Whoope, whurre, heres a sturre, never a cat, never a curre, but that we must have this demurre.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A second course.

lg.l: Pull, and pull hard
For all that hath lately bin prepar'd
For the great wedding feast.
As chiefe.
Of Doughtyes Surloine of rost Beefe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: 'Tis come, 'tis come.

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: Where hath it all this while beene?

lg.l: Some
Delay hath kept it, now 'tis here,
For bottles next of wine and beere,
The Merchants cellers they shall pay for't.
Well,
What sod or rost meat more, pray tell.
Pul for the Poultry, Foule, & Fish,
For emptie shall not be a dish.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A pox take them, must only they feed upon hot meat, and I upon nothing but cold sallads

lg.l: This meat is tedious, now some Farie,
Fetch what belongs unto the Dairie.
Thats Butter, Milk, Whey, Curds and Cheese,
Wee nothing by the bargaine leese.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Goody Dickison.
sp.p: Boy, theres meat for you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Thanke you.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickis
sp.p: And drinke too.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: What Beast was by thee hither rid?

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: A Badger nab.

lg.l: And I bestrid
A Porcupine that never prickt.
The dull sides of a Beare I kickt.
I know how you rid Lady Nan,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, upon the knave my man.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A murrein take you, I am sure my hoofes payd for't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Meat lie there, for thou hast no taste, and drinke there, for thou hast no relish, for in neither of them is there either salt or savour.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pull for the posset, pull.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: The brides posset on my life, nay if they come to their spoone meat once, I hope theil breake up their feast presently.

lg.l: So those that are our waiters nere,
Take hence this Wedding cheere.
