We will be lively all, and make this barn our hall.
You our Familiers, come.
In speech let all be dumbe,
And to close up our Feast,
To welcome every gest
A merry round let's daunce.
Some Musicke then ith aire
Whilest thus by paire and paire,
We nimbly foot it; strike.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: We are obeyd.

sp.speaker: Sprite.
sp.p: And we hels ministers shall lend our aid.

div.stage: Dance and Song together. In the time of which the Boy speakes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now whilest they are in their jollitie, and do not mind me, ile steale away, and shift for my selfe, though I lose my life for't.

lg.l: Enough, enough, now part,
To see the brides vext heart,
The bridegroomes too and all,
That vomit up their gall
For lacke o'th wedding chere.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickison.
sp.p: But stay, wheres the Boy, looke out, if he escape us, we are all betrayed.

lg.l: No following further, yonder horsemen come,
In vaine is our pursuit, let's breake up court.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickison.
sp.p: Where shall we next met?

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: At Mill.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: But when?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: At Night.

lg.l: To horse, to horse.
2. Where's my Mamilian.
1. And my Mamilian.
3. My Tyger to bestri'd.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My Puggie.

lg.l: My horse.
The night we have Feasted, now comes on the day.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Away, away,

lg.l: Come sirrah, stoope your head like a tame jade,
Whil'st I put on your Bridle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I pray Mistresse ride me as you would be rid.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: That's at full speed,

sp.speaker: Rob.

lg.l: Nay then Ile try Conclusions.
Mare Mare, see thou be,
And where I point thee carry me.

sp.stage: A great noyse within at their parting. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Generous, making him ready.

lg.l: I see what Man is loath to entertaine,
Offers it selfe to him most frequently,
And that which we most covet to embrace,
Doth seldome court us, and proves most averse;
For I, that never coo'd conceive a thought
Of this my woman worthy a rebuke,
(As one that in her youth bore her so fairely
That she was taken for a seeming Saint)
To render me such just occasion,
That I should now distrust her in her age;
Distrust! I cannot, that would bring me in
The poore aspersion of fond jealousie;
Which even from our first meeting I abhorr'd.
The Gentile fashion sometimes we observe
To sunder beds; but most in these hot monthes
Iune, Iuly August, so we did last night.
Now I (as ever tender of her health)
And therefore rising early as I use,
Entring her Chamber to bestow on her
A custom'd Visite; finde the Pillow swell'd,
Vnbruis'd with any weight, the sheets unruffled,
The Curtaines neither drawne, nor bed layd down;
Which showes, she slept not in my house to night.
Should there be any contract betwixt her
And this my Groome, to abuse my honest trust;
I should not take it well, but for all this
Yet cannot I be jealous. Robin—
Is my horse safe, lusty, and in good plight?
What, feeds he well?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes sir, he's broad buttock'd and full flanck'd, he doth not bate an ace of his flesh.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: When was he rid last?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Not sir since you backt him.

lg.l: Sirrah, take heed I finde you not a Knave,
Have you not lent him to your Mistresse late?
So late as this last Night?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Who I sir, may I dye sir, if you finde me in a lye sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Then I shall finde him where I left him last.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: No doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Give me the Key o'th Stable.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: There Sir.

lg.l: Sirrah, your Mistresse was abroad all night,
Nor is she yet come home, if there I finde him not,
I shall finde thee, what to this present houre
I never did suspect; and I must tell theee
Will not be to thy profit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Well sir, finde what you can, him you shall finde, and what you finde else; it may befor that, instead of Gramercy horse, you may say Gramercy Robin; you will beleeve there are no Witches! had I not been late brideled, I coo'd have sayd more, but I hope she is ty'd to the racke that will confesse something, and though not so much as I know, yet no more then I dare justifie—
Have you found your Gelding sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I hope not spurr'd, nor put into a sweat, you may see by his plump belly and sleeke legs he hath not bin sore travail'd.

lg.l: Y'are a sawcy Groome to receive horses
Into my Stable, and not aske me leave.
Is't for my profit to buy Hay and Oates
For every strangers jades?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I hope sir you finde none feeding there but your owne, if there be any you suspect, they have nothing to champeon, but the Bridle.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Sirrah, whose jade is that ty'd to the Racke?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: The Mare you meane sir?

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Yes, that old Mare.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Old doe you call her? You shall finde the marke still in her mouth, when the Bridle is out of it? I can assure you 'tis your owne Beast.

lg.l: A beast thou art to tell me so, hath the wine
Not yet left working? not the Myter wine?
That made thee to beleeve Witcheraft?
Prithee perswade me,
To be a drunken Sot like to thy selfe;
And not to know mine owne.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ile not perswade you to any thing, you will beleeve nothing but what you see, I say the Beast is your owne, and you have most right to keepe her, shee hath cost you more the currying, then all the Combs in your Stable are worth. You have paid for her Provender this twentie yeares and upwards, and furnisht her with all the Caparisons that she hath worne, of my Knowledge, and because she hath been ridden hard the last Night, doe you renounce her now?

lg.l: Sirrah, I feare some stolne jade of your owne
That you would have me keepe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am sure I found her no iade the last time I rid her, she carried me the best part of a hundred Miles in lesse then a quarter of an houre.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: The divell she did!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yes so I say, either the diuell or she did; an't please you walke in and take off her Bridle, and then tell me who hath more right to her, you or I.

lg.l: Well Robert, for this once Ile play the Groome,
And doe your office for you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I pray doe Sir, but take heed lest when the Bridle is out of her mouth, she put it not into yours; if she doe, you are a gone man: if she but say once— Horse, horse, see thou be. Be you rid (if you please) for me.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Generous and Mrs. Generous, he with a Bridle.

lg.l: My blood is turn'd to Ice, and my all vitals
Have ceas'd their working! dull stupidity
Surpriseth me at once, and hath arrested
That vigorous agitation; Which till now
Exprest a life within me: I me thinks
Am a meere Marble statue, and no man;
Vnweave my age O time, to my first thread;
Let me loose fiftie yeares in ignorance spent:
That being made an infant once againe,
I may begin to know, what? or where am I
To be thus lost in wonder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen.
sp.p: Sir.

lg.l: Amazement still pursues me, how am I chang'd
Or brought ere I can understand my selfe,
Into this new World.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You will beleeve no Witches?

lg.l: This makes me beleeve all, I any thing;
And that my selfe am nothing: prithee Robin
Lay me to my selfe open, what art thou,
Or this new transform'd Creature?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am Robin, and this your wife, my Mrs.

lg.l: Tell me the Earth
Shall leave it's seat, and mount to kisse the Moone;
Or that the Moone enamour'd of the Earth,
Shall leave her spheare, to stoope to us thus low.
What? what's this in my hand, that at an instant
Can from a foure leg'd Creature, make a thing
So like a wife?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A Bridle, jugling Bridle Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.

lg.l: A Bridle, hence inchantment,
A Viper were more safe within my hand
Then this charm'd Engine

sp.stage: Casts it away. Robin takes it up.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Take heed Sir what you do, if you cast it hence, and she catch it up, we that are here now, may be rid as far as the Indies within these few houres, Mistresse down of your Mares bones, or your Mary-bones whether you please, and confesse your selfe to be what you are; and that's in plaine English a Witch, a grand notorius Witch.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: A Witch! my wife a Witch!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: So it appeares by the storie.

lg.l: The more I strive to unwinde
My selfe from this Meander, I the more
Therein am intricated; prithee woman
Art thou a Witch?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: It cannot be deny'd, I am such a curst Creature.

lg.l: Keep aloofe, and doe not come too neare me, O my trust;
Have I since first I understood my selfe,
Bin of my soule so charie, still to studie
What best was for it's health, to renounce all
The workes of that black Fiend with my best force
And hath that Serpent twin'd me so about,
That I must lye so often and so long
With a Divell in my bosome!

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Pardon sir.

lg.l: Pardon! Can such a thing as that be hop'd?
Lift up thine eyes (lost woman) to yon Hils;
It must be thence expected: look not down
Vnto that horrid dwelling, which thou hast sought
At such deare rate to purchase, prithee tell me,
(For now I can beleeve) art thou a Witch?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I am.

lg.l: With that word I am thunderstrooke,
And know not what to answer, yet resolve me
Hast thou made any contract with that Fiend
The Enemy of Mankind?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: O I have.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What? and how farre?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I have promis'd him my soule.

lg.l: Ten thousand times better thy Body had
Bin promis'd to the Stake, I and mine too,
To have suffer'd with thee in a hedge of flames:
Then such a compact ever had bin made. Oh—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What cheese sir, show your selfe a man, though she appear'd so late a Beast; Mistresse confesse all, better here than in a worse place, out with it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Resolve me, how farre doth that contract stretch?

lg.l: What interest in this Soule, my selfe coo'd claime
I freely gave him, but his part that made it
I still reserve, not being mine to give.
O cunning Divell, foolish woman know
Where he can clayme but the least little part,
He will usurpe the whole; thou art a lost woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I hope not so.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Why hast thou any hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Yes Sir I have.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Make it appeare to me.

lg.l: I hope I never bargain'd for that fire,
Further then penitent teares have power to quench.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I would see some of them.

lg.l: You behold them now.
(If you looke on me with charitable eyes)
Tinctur'd in blood, blood issuing from the heart,
Sir I am sorry; when I looke towards Heaven
I beg a gracious Pardon; when on you
Me thinkes your Native goodnesse should not be
Lesse pittifull than they: 'gainst both I have err'd,
From both I beg attonement.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: May I presum't?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I kneele to both your Mercies.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Know'st thou what a Witch is?

lg.l: Alas, None better,
Or after mature recollection can be
More sad to thinke on't.
Tell me, are those teares
As full of true hearted penitence,
As mine of sorrow, to behold what state
What desperate state th'art falne in.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Sir they are.

lg.l: Rise, and as I doe, so heaven pardon me;
We all offend, but from such falling off,
Defend us. Well, I doe remember wife,
When I first tooke thee, 'twas for good and bad;
O change thy bad to good, that I may keep thee,
As then we past our faiths, till Death us sever.
I will not aggravate thy griefe too much,
By Needles iteration: Robin hereafter
Forget thou hast a tongue, if the least Syllable
Of what hath past be rumour'd, you loose me;
But if I finde you faithfull, you gaine me ever.
A match sir, you shall finde me as mute as if I had the
Bridle still in my mouth.
O woman thou had'st need to weepe thy selfe
Into a fountaine, such a penitent spring
As may have power to quench invisible flames
In which my eyes shall ayde; too little all,
If not too little, all's forgiven, forgot;
Only thus much remember, thou had'st extermin'd
Thy selfe out of the blest society
Of Saints and Angels, but on thy repentance
I take thee to my Bosome, once againe,
My wife, sister, and daughter: saddle my Gelding,
Some businesse that may hold me for two dayes
Calls me aside.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I shall Sir, well now my Mistresse hath promis'd to give over her Witchery, I hope though I still continue her man, yet she will make me no more her journey-man; to prevent which the first thing I doe shall be to burne the Bridle, and then away with the Witch.

sp.speaker: Arth
sp.p: Sir you have done a right noble courtesie, which deserves a memory, as long as the name of friendship can beare mention.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: What I have done, I ha'done, if it be well, 'tis well, J doe not like the bouncing of good Offices, if the little care I have taken shall doe these poore people good, I have my end in't, and so my reward.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, you seeme very serious.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: 'Tis true we are so, but you are welcome to the knowledge of our affayres.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: How does thine Vncle and Aunt, Gregory and his sister, the Families of Seelyes agree yet, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: That is the businesse, the Seely houshold is divided now.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: How so I pray?

lg.l: You know, and cannot but with pitty know
Their miserable condition, how
The good old couple were abus'd, and how
The young abus'd themselves; if we may say
That any of hem are their selves at all
Which sure we cannot, nor approve them fit
To be their owne disposers, that would give
The governance of such a house and living
Into their Vassailes hands, to thrust them out on't
Without or Law or order, this consider'd
This Gentleman and my selfe have taken home
By faire entreaty, the old folkes to his house,
The young to mine, untill some wholesome order
By the judicious of the Common-wealth,
Shall for their persons and estate be taken.
But what becomes of Lawrénce and his Parnell?
The lusty couple, what doe they now?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Alas poore folks, they are as farre to seeke of how they doe, or what they doe, or what they should doe, as any of the rest, they are all growne Ideots, and till some of these damnable jades, with their divellish devises bee found out, tod scharme them, no remedy can be found, I mean to lay the Country for their Hagships, and if J can anticipate the purpose, of their grand Mr. Divell to confound'em before their lease be out, be sure ile do 't.

sp.speaker: Cry.
sp.p: A Skimington, a Skimmington, a Skimington.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Whats the matter now, is Hell broke loose?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Tom Shakstone, how now, canst tell the newes?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: The news, ye heare it up i'th aire, do you not?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: A Skimington, a Skimington, a Skimington.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Hearke ye, do you not heare it? theres a Skimington, towards gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Ware Wedlocke hoe.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: At whose suit I prithee is Don Skimington come to towne.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Ile tell you gentlemen, since you have taken home old Seely and his wife to your house, and you their son and daughter to yours, the house-keepers Lawrence, and his late bride Parnell are fallen out by themselves.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: The quarell began they say upon the wedding night, and in the bride bed.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: For want of bedstaves?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: No but a better implement it seemes the bridegroome was unprovided of, a homely tale to tell.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Now out upon her shee has a greedy worme in her, I have heard the fellow complain'd on, for an over mickle man among the maids.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Is his haste to goe to bed at afternoone come to this now?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Witchery, witchery, more witcherie still flat and plaine witchery. Now do I thinke upon the codpeece point the young jade gave him at the wedding: shee is a witch, and that was a charme, if there be any in the World.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A ligatory point.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Alas poore Lawrence.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: He's comming to make his mone to you about it, and she too, since you have taken their masters & mistresses to your care, you must do them right too.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Marry but ile not undertake her at these yeares, if lusty Lawrence cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: But has she beaten him?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Grievously broke his head in I know not how many places: of which the hoydens have taken notice, and will have a Skimmington on horse-backe presently. Looke ye, here comes both plaintiffe and defendant.

sp.speaker: Dough
sp.p: How now Lawrence, what has thy wedlock brought thee already to thy night-cap?

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Yie gadwat sir, I ware wadded but aw to seun.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Han yeou reeson to complayne or ay trow yeou gaffer Downought? Wa warth the day that ever I wadded a Downought.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ban. Sha.
sp.p: Nay hold Parnel hold.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: We have heard enough of your valour already, wec know you have beaten him, let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Ware ever poore mayden betrayed as ay ware unto a swagbellied Carle that cannot aw waw that cannot.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: What saies she?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: I know not, she catterwawles I think. Parnel be patient good Parnell, and a little modest too, 'tis not amisse, wee know not the relish of every eare that heares vs, lets talke within our selves. Whats the defect? Whats the impediment? Lawrence has had a lusty name among the Batchellors.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What he ware when he ware a Batchelor, I know better than the best maid ith tawne. I wad I had not.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ba. Sha.
sp.p: Peace Parnell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: 'Tware that, that cossen'd me, he has not now as he had than?

sp.speaker: Ar. Ba. Sha.
sp.p: Peace good Parnell.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: For then he could, but now he connot, he connot.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ba. Sha
sp.p: Fie Parnel fie.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I say agean and agean, hee connot, he connot.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ba Sha.
sp.p: Alas poore Parnel.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I am not a bit the better for him sin wye ware wad. Cries

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Heres good stuffe for a jurie of women to passe upon.

lg.l: But Parnel, why have you beaten him so grievously?
What would you have him doe in this case?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: He's out of a doing case it seemes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Marry sir, and beat him will I into his grave, or backe to the Priest, and be unwaddded agone, for I wonot bee baund to lig with him and live with him the laife of an honest woman for aw the layves good i' Loncoshire.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: An honest woman: thats a good mind Parnel What say you to this Lawrence?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Keepe her of o'me, and I shan teln yeou, and she be by I am no body: But keep her off and search me, let me be searcht as never witch was searcht, and finde ony thing mor or lasse upo me than a sufficient mon shold have, and let me be honckt by't.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Do you heare this Parnell?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ah leear, leear, deell tacke the leear, troist yee and hong yee.

lg.l: Alasse it is too plaine, the poore fellow is bewitcht.
Heres a plaine Maleficium versus hanc now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: And so is she bewitcht too into this immodesty.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.p: She would never talke so else

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: I prayn yeow gi' me the lere o'that Latine sir.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: The meaning is, you must get halfe a dozen bastards Within this twelvemoneth, and that will mend your next mariage.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: And I thought it would ma' Parnel, love me i'd be sure on't, and gang about it now right.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Y'are soone provided it seems for such a journey.

sp.speaker: Dou
sp.p: Best tarry till thy head be whole Lawrence.

lg.l: Nay, nay, ay's white casten away ent I be vnwadded agen▪
And then ine undertack to find 3 better husbands in a bean cod.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Hearke gentlemen, the shew is comming.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: What shall we stay & see't.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.p: O by all means Gent.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: 'Tis best to have these away first.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Nay mary shan eou not sir, I heare yeou well enogh, & I con the meaning o'the show well enogh, & I stay not the show & see not the show, & ma'one i'the show, let me be honckt up for a show ile ware them to mel or ma with a woman that mels or mae's with a testril a longie, a dow little losell that connot, & if I skim not their skimingtons cockskeam for't, ma that warplin boggle me a week lonker, & thats a curse eno' for any wife I tro.
from the boord, and yet for ought I can see I am never a whit the neerer What not one kisse at parting Mal?

lg.l: Well Cozen this is all you have to do:
Retire the Gallants to some privat roome,
Where call for wine, and junckets what you please,
Then thou shalt need to do no other thing
Than what this note directs thee, observe that
An trouble me no farther.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Very good, I like this beginning well: for where they sleighted me before, they shall finde me a man of note.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Of this the meaning

lg.l: Marry Lasse
To bring a new conceit to passe.
Thy Spirit must borrow more,
To fill the number three or foure;
Whom we will use to no great harm,
Only assist me with thy charme.
This night wee'l celebrate to sport:
'Tis all for mirth, we mean no hurt.
My Spirit and my selfe command;
Mamillion, & the rest at hand, shall all assist.
Withdraw then, quicke,
Now gallants, ther's for you a trick.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Heer's a more privat roome gentlemen, free from the noise of the Hall. Here we may talke, and throw the chamber out of the casements. Some wine and a short banquet.

div.stage: Enter with a boquet, Wine, and two Tapers.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: So now leave us.

lg.l: Wee are much bound to you master Whetstone.
For this great entertainment: I see you command
The house in the absence of your vnkle.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Yes, I thanke my Aunt; for though I be but a daily guest yet I can be welcome to her at midnight.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: How shall we passe the time?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: In some discourse.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: But no such discourse as we had last, beseech you.

lg.l: Now master Whetstone you reflect on me.
'Tis true, at our last meeting some few words
Then past my lips, which I could wish forgot:
I thinke I call'd you Bastard.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I thinke so too; but whats that amongst friends, for I would faine know which amongst you all knowes his owne father.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You are merrie with your friends, good master By-Blow, and wee are guests here in your Vnckles house, and therefore priviledged.

div.stage: Enter Mistresse Generous, Mal and Spirits.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I presume you had no more priviledge in your getting than I. But tell me gentlemen, is there any man here amongst you, that hath a minde to see his father?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why, who shall shew him?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Thats all one; if any man here desire it, let him but speake the word, and 'tis sufficient.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why, I would see my father.

sp.speaker: Mistresse Gener.
sp.p: Strike.

div.stage: Enter a Pedant dauncing to the musique; the strain don, he points at Bantam, & looks full in his face.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Doe you know him that lookes so full in your face;

lg.l: Yes well, a pedant in my fathers house.
Who beeing young, taught me my A, B, C.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: In his house, that goes for your father you would say: For know one morning, when your mothers husband rid early to have a Nisi prius tryed at Lancaster Syzes, hee crept into his warme place, lay close by her side, and then were you got. Then come, your heeles and tayle together, and kneele unto your own deare father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: I am abused.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Why laugh you Gentlemen? It may be more mens cases than his or mine. Bant. To be thus geer'd.

lg.l: Come, take it as a jest
For presume 'twas meant no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Would either of you two now see his father in earnest

sp.speaker: Shak
sp.p: Yes, canst thou shew me mine?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen.
sp.p: Strike.

div.stage: Enter a nimble Taylor dauncing, using the same posture to Shakstone.

sp.speaker: Whet
sp.p: Hee lookes on you speake, doe you know him?

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Yes, he was my mothers Taylor, I remember him ever since I was a childe.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Who when hee came to take measure of her upper parts had more minde to the lower, whilest the good man was in the fields hunting, he was at home whoring.

lg.l: Then, since no better comfort can be had,
Come downe, come downe, aske blessing of your dad.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: This cannot be indur'd.

lg.l: It is plaine Witchcraft.
Nay since we all are bid unto one feast,
Lets fare alike, come shew me mine too.

sp.speaker: Mrs Gener.
sp.p: Strike.

div.stage: Enter Robin with a switch and a Currycombe, he points at Arthur.

sp.speaker: Whet
sp.p: He points at you.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: You know him.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes, Robin the groome belonging to this house.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: And never served your father?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: In's youth I thinke he did.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p:
Who when your supposed father had businesse at the Lord Presidents Court in Yorke, stood for his Atturney at home, & so it seems you were got by deputy: what all a mort? if
you will have but a little patience, stay & you shall see mine too:

lg.l: And know I shew you him the rather,
To finde who hath the best man to his Father.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Strike—

div.stage: Musicke. Enter a Gallant, as before to him.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen make me your President, learne your duties, and doe as I doe— A blessing Dad.

lg.l: Come, come, let's home, we'l finde some other time,
When to dispute of these things—

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: : Nay Gent. no parting in spleene, since we have begun in mirth, let's not end in melancholy; you see there are more By-blowes than beare the name; It is growne a great kindred in the Kingdome. Come, come, all friends; Let's into the Cellar and conclude our Revels in a lusty health.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: I faine would strike, but cannot.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Some strange fate holds me.

lg.l: Here then all anger end,
Let none be mad at what they cannot mend.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Now say what's next?

lg.l: I'th' Mill there lyes
A Souldier yet with unscratcht eyes,
Summon the Sister-hood together
For we with all our Spirits will thither;
And such a Catterwalling keepe,
That he in vaine shall thinke to sleepe.
Call Meg, and Doll, Tib, Nab, and Iug,
Let none appeare without her Pug.
We'l try our utmost Art and skill.
To fright the stout Knave in the Mill.

div.head: ACTVS, V. SCENA, I.
div.stage: Enter Doughty, Miller, Boy in a Cap.

sp.speaker: Doughty..
sp.p: THou art a brave Boy, the honour of thy Country; thy Statue shall be set up in brasse upon the Market Crosse in Lancaster, I blesse the time that I answered at the Font for thee: 'Zookes did I ever think that a Godson of mine should have fought hand to fist with the Divell!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: He was ever an unhappy Boy Sir, and like enough to grow acquainted with him; and friends may fall out sometimes.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Thou art a dogged Sire, and doest not know the vertue of my Godsonne, my sonne now; he shall be thy sonne no longer: he and I will worry all the Witches in Lancashire.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You were best take heed though.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: I care not, though we leave not above three untainted women in the Parish, we'll doe it.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Doe what you please Sir, there's the Boy stout enough to justifie any thing he has sayd. Now 'tis out, he should be my Sonne still by that: Though he was at Death's dore before he would reveale any thing, the damnable jades had so threatned him, and as soone as ever he had told he mended.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: 'Tis well he did so, we will so swing them in two-penny halters Boy.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: For my part I have no reason to hinder any thing that may root them all out; I have tasted enough of their mischiefe, witnesse my usage i' th Mill, which could be nothing but their Roguerie. One night in my sleepe they set me a stride stark naked a top of my Mill, a bitter cold night too; 'twas day light before I waked, and I durst never speake of it to this houre, because I thought it impossible to be beleeved.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Villanous Hags

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And all last Summer, my Wife could not make a bit of butter.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: It would not come, would it?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: No Sir, we could not make it come, though she and I both together, churn'd almost our harts out, and nothing would come, but all ran into thin waterish geere: the Pigges would not drinke it.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: None but one, and he ran out of his wits upon't, till we bound his head, and layd him a sleepe, but he has had a wry mouth ever since.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: That the Divell should put in their hearts to delight in such Villanies! I have sought about these two dayes, and heard of a hundred such mischievous tricks, though none mortall, but could not finde whom to mistrust for a Witch till now this boy, this happy boy informes me.

And they should neere have been sought for me if their affrightments and divelish devices, had not brought my Boy into such a sicknesse; Whereupon indeed I thought good to acquaint your worship, and bring the Boy unto you being his Godfather, and as you now stick not to say his Father.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: After you I thanke yon Gossip. But my Boy thou hast satisfied me in their names, and thy knowledge of the women, their turning into shapes, their dog-trickes, and their horse trickes, and their great Feast in the Barne (a pox take them with my Surloyne, I say still.) But a little more of thy combat with the Divell, I prithee; he came to thee like a Boy thou sayest, about thine owne bignesse?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and he asked me where I dwelt, and what my name was.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Ah Rogue!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But it was in a quarrelsome way; Whereupon I was as stout, and ask'd him who made him an examiner?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Ah good Boy.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: In that he was my Sonne.

lg.l: He told me he would know or beat it out of me,
And I told him he should not, and bid him doe his worst;
And to't we went.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: In that he was my sonne againe, ha boy; I see him at it now.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: We fought a quarter of an houre, till his sharpe nailes made my eares bleed.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: O the grand Divell pare 'em.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I wondred to finde him so strong in my hands, seeming but of mine owne age and bignesse, till I looking downe, perceived he had clubb'd cloven feet like Oxe feet; but his face was as young as mine.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: A pox, but by his feet, he may be the Club-footed Horse-coursers father, for all his young lookes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But I was afraid of his feet, and ran from him towards a light that I saw, and when I came to it, it was one of the Witches in white upon a Bridge, that scar'd me backe againe, and then met me the Boy againe, and he strucke me and layd mee for dead.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Till I wondring at his stay, went out and found him in the Trance; since which time, he has beene haunted and frighted with Goblins, 40. times, and never durst tell any thing (as I sayd) because the Hags had so threatned him till in his sicknes he revealed it to his mother.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: And she told no body but folkes on't. Well Gossip Gretty, as thou art a Miller, and a close thiefe, now let us keepe it as close as we may till we take 'hem, and see them handsomly hanged o' the way: Ha my little Cusse-divell, thou art a made man. Come, away with me.

lg.l: These two nights I have slept well and heard no noise
Of Cats, or Rats; most sure the fellow dream't,
And scratcht himselfe in 's sleep. I have traveld' Desarts,
Beheld Wolves, Beares, and Lyons: Indeed what not?
Of horrid shape; And shall I be afrayd
Of Cats in mine owne Country? I can never
Grow so Mouse-hearted. It is now a Calme
And no winde stirring, I can beare no sayle;
Then best lye downe to sleepe. Nay rest by me
Good Morglay, my Comrague and Bedfellow
That never fayl'd me yet; I know thou did'st not.
If I be wak'd, see thou be stirring too;
Then come a Gib as big as Ascapart
We'l make him play at Leap-frog. A brave Souldiers lodging,
The floore my Bed, a Milstone for my Pillow,
The Sayles for Curtaynes. So good night.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Generous, Mall, all the Witches and their Spirits (at severall dores.)

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Is Nab come?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Where's Jug?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: But where's Peg?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Entred the Mill already.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Is he fast?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As sencelesse as a Dormouse.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Then to work, to work my pretty Laplands
Doe that within, without we'l keep the watch.

div.stage: The Witches retired: the Spirits come about him with a dreadfull noise: he starts.

lg.l: Am I in Hell, then have among'st you divels;
This side, and that side, what behinde, before?
Ile keep my face unscratch'd dispight you all:
What, doe you pinch in private, clawes I feele
But can see nothing, nothing pinch me thus?
Have at you then, I and have at you still;
And stil have at you.
lg.stage: Beates them off, followes them in, and Enters againe.
lg.l: One of them I have pay'd
In leaping out oth' hole a foot or eare
Or something I have light on. What all gone?
All quiet? not a Cat that's heard to mew?
Nay then Ile try to take another nap,
Though I sleepe with mine eyes open.
Robin, the last night that I lodgd at home
My Wife (if thou remembrest) lay abroad,
But no words of that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You have taught me silence.

lg.l: I rose thus early much before my houre,
To take her in her bed; 'Tis yet not five:
The Sunne scarce up. Those horses take and lead'em
Into the Stable, see them rubb'd and drest,
We have rid hard. Now in the interim I
Will step and see how my new Miller fares,
Or whether he slept better in his charge,
Than those which did precede him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: But one thing more—

lg.l: Now from the last nights witchcraft we are freed,
And I that had not power to cleare my selfe
From base aspersion, am at liberty
For vow'd revenge: I cannot be at peace
(The night-spell being took of) till I have met
With noble Mr. Generous: in whose search
The best part of this morning I have spent,
His wife now I suspect.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: By your leave Sir.

lg.l: O y'are well met, pray tell me how long is't
Since you were first my Father?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Be patient I beseech you, what doe you meane Sir?

lg.l: But that I honour
Thy Master, to whose goodnesse I am bound,
And still must remaine thankfull, I should prove
Worse than a Murderer, a meere Paricide
By killing thee my Father.
I your Father? he was a man I alwayes lov'd
And honour'd. He bred me.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And you begot me? oh you us'd me finely last night?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Pray what's the matter Sir?

lg.l: My worthy friend, but that I honour you
As one to whom I am so much obligd,
This Villaine could not stirre a foot from hence
Till perisht by my sword.
How hath he wrong'd you?
Be of a milder temper I intreat,
Relate what and when done?
You may command me,
If aske me what wrongs, know this Groome pretends
He hath strumpeted my mother, if when, blaz'd
Last night at midnight. If you aske me further
Where, in your own house; when he pointed to me
As had I been his Bastard.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I doe this? I am a horse agen if I got you, Master, why Master.

lg.l: I know you Mr. Arthur, for a Gentleman
Of faire endowments, a most solid braine,
And setled understanding. Why this fellow
These two dayes was scarce sundred from my side,
And for the last night I am most assur'd
He slept within my Chamber, 12. miles off,
We have nere parted since.
You tell me wonders.
Since all your words to me are Oracles,
And such as I most constantly beleeve.
But Sir, shall I be bold and plaine withall,
I am suspitious all's not well at home;
I dare proceed no farther without leave,
Yet there is something lodged within my breast
Which I am loath to utter.
Keepe it there,
I pray doe a season (O my feares)
In my Vncles absence who but I should comfort my Aunt,
Am I not of the Bloud, am not I next of Kin?
Why Aunt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen
sp.p: Good Nephew leave me.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: The Divell shall leave you ere ile forsake you, Aunt, you know, Sic is So, and being so sicke doe you thinke ile leave you, what know I but this Bed may prove your death-bed, and and then I hope you will remember me, that is, remember me in your Will.
Who's that knocks with such authority. Ten to one my Vncles come to towne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen.
sp.p: If it be so, excuse my weaknes to him, say I can speake with none.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I will, and scape him if I can; by this accident all must come out, and here's no stay for me
Againe, stay you here with your Aunt, and ile goe let in your Vncle.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Doe good Mal, and how, and how sweet Aunt?

div.stage: Enter Mr. Gener. Mal, Arthur, Soldier, and Robin.

lg.l: Y'are well met here, I am told you oft frequent
This house as my Wives choyse companion,
Yet have I seldome seene you.
Pray, by your leave Sir,
Your wife is taken with a suddaine qualme
She hath sent me for a Doctor.
But that labour ile save you, Soldier take her to your charge.
And now where's this sicke woman.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: O Vncle you come in good time, my Aunt is so suddainly taken as if she were ready to give up the spirit.

lg.l: 'Tis almost time she did, speake how is't wife
My Nephew tels me you were tooke last night
With a shrewd sicknesse, which this Mayde confirmes.
Yes sir, but now desire no company.
Noyse troubles me, and I would gladly sleepe.
In company there's comfort, prithee wife
Lend me thy hand, and let me feele thy pulse,
Perhaps some Feaver, by their beating I
May guesse at thy disease.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen.
sp.p: My hand, 'tis there.

lg.l: A dangerous sicknes, and I feare t death,
'Tis oddes you will not scape it. Take that backe
And let me prove the t'other, if perhaps
I there can finde more comfort.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen.
sp.p: I pray excuse me.

lg.l: I must not be deny'd,
Sick folkes are peevish, and must be ore-rul'd, and so shall you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gen.
sp.p: Alas I have not strength to lift it up.

lg.l: If not thy hand Wife, shew me but thy wrist,
And see how this will match it, here's a Testate
That cannot be out-fac'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gener.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Hath my Aunt bin playing at handee dandee, nay then if the game goe this way I feare she'l have the worst hand on't.

lg.l: 'Tis now apparant
How all the last nights businesse came about,
In this my late suspicion, is confirm'd.
My heart hath bled more for thy curst relapse
Than drops hath issu'd from thy wounded arme.
But wherefore should I preach to one past hope?
Or where the divell himselfe claimes right in all,
Seeke the least part or interest? Leave your Bed,
Vp, make you ready; I must deliver you
Into the hand of Iustice. O deare friend
It is in vaine to guesse at this my griefe
'Tis so inundant. Soldier take away that young
But old in mischiefe.
And being of these Apostat's rid so well,
Ile see my house no more be made a Hell.
Away with them.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.p: Ile out o'the Country, and as soone live in Lapland as Lancashire hereafter.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: What for a false illusive apparition? I hope the divell is not able to perswade thee thou art a Bastard.

sp.speaker: Bant
sp.p: No, but I am afflicted to thinke that the divell should have power to put such a trick upon us, to countenance a Rascal, that is one.

sp.speaker: Shak
sp.p: J hope Arthur has taken a course with his Vncle about him by this time, who would have thought such a foole as hee could have beene a Witch?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why doe you thinke there's any wise folks of the quality; Can any but fooles be drawne into a Covenant with the greatest enemy of mankind? yet J cannot thinke that Whetstone is the Witch? The young Queane that was at the Wedding was i'th house yee know.

div.stage: Enter Lawrence and Parnell, in their first Habits.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: See Lawrence and Parnell civilly accorded againe it seems, and accoutred as they were wont to be when they had their wits.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Blest be the houre I say may hunny, may sweet Pall, that Ay's becom'd thaine agone, and thou's becom'd maine agone, and may this ea kisse ma us tway become both eane for ever and a day.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Yie marry Lall, and thus shadden it be, there is nought getten by fawing out, we mun faw in or we get nought.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: The world's well mended here; we cannot but rejoyce to see this, Lawrence.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And you been welcome to it Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: And we been glad we han it for you.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: And I protest I am glad to see it.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: And thus shan yeou see't till our deeing houre.
Ween eon leove now for a laife time, the Dewle shonot ha the poore to put us to peeces agone.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why now all's right and straight and as it should be.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p:
Yie marry that is it, the good houre be blessed for it, that put the wit into may head, to have a mistrust of that pestilent Codpeece-point, that the witched worch Mal Spencer go
me, ah woe worth her, that were it that made aw so nought.

sp.speaker: Bant. & Shak.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Yie marry it were an Inchauntment, and about an houre since it come intill our hearts to doe, what yeou thinke, and we did it.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: What Parnell?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Marry we take the point, and we casten the point into the fire, and the point spitter'd and spatter'd in the fire, like an it were (love blesse us) a laive thing in the faire; and it hopet and skippet, and riggled, and frisket in the faire, and crept about laike a worme in the faire, that it were warke enough for us both with all the Chimney tooles to keepe it into the faire, and it stinket in the faire, worsen than ony brimstone in the faire.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: This is wonderfull as all the rest.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: It wolld ha scar'd ony that hadden their wits till a seen't, and we werne mad eoht it were deone.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: And this were not above an houre since, and you connot devaise how we han lov'd t'on t'other by now, yeou woud een blisse your seln to see't.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Yie an han pit on our working geere, to swinke and serve our Master and Maistresse like intill painfull servants agone, as we shudden.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: 'Tis wondrous well.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: And are they well agen?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Yie and weel's laike heane blisse them, they are awas weel becom'd as none ill had ever beene aneast'hem; Lo ye, lo ye, as they come.

div.stage: Enter Seely, Ioane, Gregory and Win.

lg.l: Sir, if a contrite heart strucke through with sence
Of it's sharpe errors, bleeding with remorse
The blacke polluted staine it had conceived
Of foule unnaturall disobedience
May yet by your faire mercy finde Remission;
You shall upraise a Sonne out o'the gulph
Of horrour and despaire, unto a blisse
That shall for ever crowne your goodnesse, and
Instructive in my after life to serve you,
In all the duties that be fit a sonne.
Enough, enough, good boy, 'tis most apparant
We all have had our errors, and as plainly
It now appeares, our judgments, yea our reason
Was poyson'd by some violent infection,
Quite contrary to Nature.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: This sounds well.

lg.l: I feare it was by Witchcraft: for I now
(Blest be the power that wrought the happy means
Of my delivery) remember that
Some 3. months since I crost a way ward woman
(One that I now suspect) for bearing with
A most unseemly disobedience,
In an untoward ill-bred sonne of hers,
When with an ill looke and an hollow voyce
She mutter'd out these words. Perhaps erelong
Thy selfe shalt be obedient to thy sonne.
She has play'd her pranke it seemes.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Sir I have heard, that Witches apprehended under hands of lawfull authority, doe loose their power; And all their spels are instantly dissolv'd.

lg.l: If it be so, then at this happy houre,
The Witch is tane that over us had power.

sp.speaker: Joane.
sp.p: Enough Childe, thou art mine and all is well.

lg.l: Long may you live the well-spring of my blisse,
And may my duty and my fruitfull Prayers,
Draw a perpetuall streame of blessings from you.
Gentlemen welcome to my best friends house,
You know the unhappy cause that drew me hether.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And cannot but rejoyce to see the remedy so neere at hand.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Come Gossip, come Boy— Gentlemen you are come to the bravest discovery— Mr. Seely and the rest, how is't with you? you look reasonable well me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Sir, we doe find that we have reason enough to thank you for your Neighbourly and pious care of us.

sp.speaker: Doughty.
sp.p: Is all so well with you already? goe to, will you know a reason for't Gentlemen: I have catcht a whole Kennel of Witches. It seemes their Witch is one of 'hem, and so they are discharm'd, they are all in Officers hands, and they will touch here with two or three of them for a little private parley, before they goe to the Iustices. Master Generous is comming hither too, with a supply that you dreame not of, and your Nephew Arthur.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You are beholden Sir to Master Generous in behalfe of your Nephew for saving his land from forfeiture in time of your distraction.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: I will acknowledge it most thankfully.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: See he comes.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Generous, Mrs. Generous, Arthur, Wherstone, Mal, Soldier, and Robin.

lg.l: O Mr. Generous, the noble favour you have shew'd
My Nephew for ever bindes me to you.
I pittyed then your misery, and now
Have nothing left but to bewayle mine owne
In this unhappy woman.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Good Mistresse Generous—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Make a full stop there Sir, sides, sides, make sides, You know her not as I doe, stand aloofe there Mistresse with your darling Witch, your Nephew too if you please, because though he be no witch, he is a wel-willer to the infernal science.

lg.l: I utterly discard him in her blood
And all the good that I intended him
I will conferre upon this vertuous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Well Sir, though you be no Vnckle, yet mine Aunt's mine Aunt, and shall be to her dying day.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And that will be about a day after next Sizes I take it,

div.p:
O here comes more o'your Naunts, Naunt Dickenson & Naunt
Hargrave, ods fish and your Granny Johnson too; we want but a good fire to entertaine 'em.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: See how they lay their heads together?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: No succour.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: No reliefe.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No comfort!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mawsy, my Mawsy, gentle Mawsy come,

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Come my sweet Puckling.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: My Mamilion.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What doe they say?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: They call their Spirits I thinke.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Now a shame take you for a fardell of fooles, have you knowne so many of the Divels tricks, and can be ignorant of that common feate of the old Iugler; that is, to leave you all to the Law, when you are once seized on by the tallons of Authority? Ile undertake this little Demigorgon Constable with these Common-wealth Characters upon his staffe here, is able inspite of all your bugs-words, to stave off the grand Divell for doing any of you good till you come to his Kingdome to him, and there take what you can finde.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: But Gentlemen, shall we try if we can by examination get from them something that may abbreviate the cause unto the wiser in Commission for the peace before wee carry them before 'em.

sp.speaker: Gen. & Seel.
sp.p: Let it be so.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Well say, stand out Boy, stand out Miller, stand out Robin, stand out Soldier, and lay your accusation upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Speake Boy doe you know these Creatures, women I dare not call 'em?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and saw them all in the Barne together, and many more at their Feast and Witchery.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And so did I, by a Divellish token, I was rid thither, though I rid home againe as fast without switch or spur.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I was ill handled by them in the Mill.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: And I sliced off a Cats foot there, that is since a hand, who ever wants it.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: How I and all my family have suffered you all know.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And how I were betwitched my Pall. here knowes.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p:
Yie Lall, and the Witch I knaw, an I prayen yeou goe
me but leave to scrat her well-favorely.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Hold Parnell.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Yeou can blame no honest woman, I trow, to scrat for the thing she leoves.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Doe you laugh Gentlewoman? what say you to all these matters?

lg.l: I will say nothing, but what you know you know,
And as the law shall finde me let it take me.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And so say I.

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And I, other confession you get none from us.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What say you Granny?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mamilion, ho Mamilion, Mamilion.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Who's that you call?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: My friend, my Sweet-heart, my Mamilion.

sp.speaker: Witches.
sp.p: You are not mad?

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Ah ha, that's her Divell, her Incubus I warrant; take her off from the rest they'l hurt her. Come hether poore old woman. Ile dandle a Witch a little, thou wilt speake, and tell the truth, and shalt have favour doubt not. Say art not thou a Witch?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'Tis folly to dissemble yie sir, I am one.

lg.l: And that Mamilion which thou call'st upon
Is thy familiar Divell is't not? Nay prithee speake.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: That's a good woman, how long hast had's acquaintance, ha?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: A matter of sixe yeares Sir.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: A pretty matter. What was he like a man?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes when I pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: And then he lay with thee, did he not sometimes?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Tis folly to dissemble; twice a Weeke he never fail'd me.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Humh— and how? and how a little? was he a good Bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Tis folly to speake worse of him than he is.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: I trust me is't. Give the Divell his due.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He pleas'd me well Sir, like a proper man.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: There was sweet coupling.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Onely his flesh felt cold.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: He wanted his great fires about him that he has at home.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Peace, and did he weare good clothes?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Gentleman like, but blacke blacke points and all.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: I, very like his points were blacke enough. But come we'l trifle w'yee no longer. Now shall you all to the Iustices, and let them take order with you till the Sizes, and then let Law take his course, and Uivat Rex. Mr. Generous I am sorry for your cause of sorrow, we shall not have your company?

lg.l: No sir, my Prayers for her soules recovery.
Shall not be wanting to her, but mine eyes
Must never see her more.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Mal, adiew sweet Mal, ride your next journey with the company you have there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well Rogue I may live to ride in a Coach before I come to the Gallowes yet.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And Mrs. the horse that stayes for you rides better with a Halter than your gingling bridle.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Mr. Seely I rejoyce for your families attonement.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: And I praise heaven for you that were the means to it.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: On afore Drovers with your untoward Cattell.

lg.l: Why doe not you follow Mr. By-blow. I thanke your
Aunt for the tricke she would have father'd us withall.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Well Sir, mine Aunt's mine Aunt, and for that trick I will not leave her till I see her doe a worse.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Y'are a kinde Kinsman.

lg.l: 1 Come Mawsy, come Puckling,
And come my sweet Suckling,
My pretty Mamillion, my Ioy,
Fall each to his Duggy,
While kindly we buggie,
As tender as Nurse over Boy.
Then suck our blouds freely, and with it be jolly,
While merrily we sing, hey Trolly Lolly.
2 We'l dandle and clip yee,
We'l stroke yee, and leape yee,
And all that we have is your due;
The feates you doe for us,
And those which you store us
Withall, tyes us onely to you.
Then suck our blouds freely, and with it be jolly,
While merrily we sing, hey Trolly Lolly.
NOw while the Witches must expect their due
By lawfull Iustice, we appeale to you
For favourable censure; what their crime
May bring upon'em, ripenes yet of time
Has not reveal'd. Perhaps great Mercy may
After just condemnation give them day
Of longer life. We represent as much
As they have done, before Lawes hand did touch
Upon their guilt; But dare not hold it fit,
That we for Iustices and Iudges sit.
And personate their grave wisedomes on the Stage
Whom we are bound to honour; No, the Age
Allowes it not. Therefore unto the Lawes
We can but bring the Witches and their cause,
And there we leave'em, as their Divels did,
Should we goe further with'em? Wit forbid;
What of their storie, further shall ensue,
We must referre to time, our selves to you.
